name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament adjourned on Thursday, 8 October 2020.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Colleagues and gentlemen, Samuel Paty, professor of history and geography in the Yvelines, France, was brutally murdered on Friday by an Islamist terrorist because he believed in freedom of expression, because he wanted to pass on to his students the freedom of thought, the open-mindedness and the values of living together. Five years after the attack on Charlie Hebdo, the fact of showing, during its course, a caricature of Muhammad, kills. Fanaticism and intolerance kill. Our thoughts are with the family and loved ones of Samuel Paty and all the teaching staff in France and elsewhere. Terror is fought through education, through the teaching that Samuel Paty believed in and as he practiced it. A benevolent and critical teaching, open to society, to the other, advocating dialogue and knowledge. This fight is daily. It is committed by millions of teachers, who carry out their mission with courage and determination, and who need our support, the support of a society for which freedom of expression is a fundamental value and a major principle. It is with great emotion that I propose to make a minute of silence in tribute to Samuel Paty, to all the victims of terrorism and to all those who fight him on a daily basis by their profession, their commitment and their example. (The Assembly, standing, observes a minute's silence)

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: We now come to the order of business. The final draft was distributed, as approved by the Conference of Presidents on 15 October pursuant to Rule 157.  Following consultations with the political groups, I would like to submit to the House the following proposal for an amendment to the final draft agenda. Friday: The second voting session will be open from 1.15 p.m. to 2.30 p.m. and the results of the second voting session will be announced at 5 p.m. A third voting time will be added, which will be open from 6 p.m. to 7.15 p.m. and the results of the third round will be announced at 9.30 p.m. Are there any objections? There are no objections. This amendment is approved.  I would also like to inform you that, depending on the number of amendments tabled, the votes scheduled for the various shifts have been redistributed. Information on the distribution of votes is available on Parliament's website in the 'priority information and documents' section. I would also remind you that this redistribution could be subject to further changes, depending on the final number of amendments and the number of requests for split and distinct votes.  The order of business is thus established.  Let us begin with the first debate and give the presidency to Mrs Dobrev. I would like to remind everyone that we are in an emergency situation, but you know this, that the situation of the pandemic is still tormenting our countries, that it is growing and it is also natural for us to have taken and taken measures to contain the contagion, but at the same time to keep the activity of our Parliament alive. It was with great regret that we were once again unable to move our plenary to Strasbourg, but we had to limit our presence and take extraordinary measures, not least because of the conditions in Belgium and Brussels. You know that colleagues who are in the Member States will be able to take part in the debate by using the national offices of the European Parliament. This is the first time this has happened, but it seemed right. That is why I would like to thank all the political groups for adopting a measure that allows us to keep European democracy alive.

name: Klára DOBREV
text: Good afternoon, I warmly welcome you to today's debate. The next item is the joint debate on digital services and artificial intelligence. The seven reports are reporting by rapporters Agius Saliba, Wölken, Peeters, García Del Blanco, Voss and Séjourné. First, I would like to give the floor to Agius Ssaliba, one of the rapporteurs in this report. You have the word, Congressman.

name: Alex AGIUS SALIBA
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, first of all, may I remark that it is very symbolic today that the first discussion being undertaken by this Parliament by digital means, to give access to all our Members to participate, will be held on the Digital Services Act (DSA).  After months of negotiations, more than 1 000 amendments in the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection (IMCO) and a lot of hard work, this Committee agreed on a progressive and robust report on the Digital Services Act.  First of all, I would like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs working with me on the IMCO report for their transparency and also for their cooperation. I do not think that we would have been able to achieve this tangible positive result without all the support, which I hope you can confirm in tomorrow’s vote in the same way that you did during the negotiations and the vote in the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Affairs.  Today we are discussing all three DSA reports. Despite the fact that they are interlinked, they all have different scopes. The IMCO report is the one that deals with the comprehensive revision of the 20-year-old e-Commerce Directive and the first—ever internal market ex—ante instrument in the digital sector. The e—Commerce Directive is one of the most essential pieces of Union legislation and the foundation of the digital single market as we know it today. Digital transformation has profoundly changed the functioning of the global economy and of our societies, which requires an update to improve the situation in several areas. The Digital Services Act will be this first update to the legal framework on online services after 20 years. The report therefore sets the internal market and consumer protection priorities on how digital services, including online platforms and marketplaces, should be – and must be – regulated in the future. The Committee recommendations touch upon a range of issues. However, some of the fundamental points and measures that the Commission must, and should, introduce in the DSA are as follows. First of all, introduce the principle that what is illegal offline should also be illegal online, together with consumer protection and also user—safety principles. The second point is to extend the scope of the DSA to companies established outside Europe, mainly the ones targeting our European market, our European consumers and our European citizens. The third point is that the online harmful business models’ manipulation and discriminatory practices, designed to maximise user attention dedicated to the platform based on illegal or sensationalist content, must be addressed through privacy and accountability measures such as the ‘Know Your Business Customer’ principle. The ‘Know Your Business Customer’ is a new obligation on platforms to check and stop fraudulent companies from using their services. Such a measure would reduce the number of illegitimate traders and illegal activities online.  The Commission must promote transparent advertising practices that do not track our consumers and users through the Net. To this end, the DSA should include stricter measures on harmful advertising practices, digital nudging, microtargeting, recommended systems for advertisement, and also preferential treatment.  Another essential element in my report is targeted measures on online marketplaces and here we have dedicated a whole chapter in our report targeting online marketplaces such as Amazon and Alibaba. Consumers should be equally safe when shopping online or in stores and the Commission must, and should, address and reinforce liability for online marketplaces.  The report also deals with the e-Commerce Directive’s fundamental parts, dealing with the liability regime when removing illegal content online. Finally, we are also proposing, for the first time in the digital sector, ex—ante rules to tackle the digital players’ uncompetitive practice. The Commission must, and should, introduce this as a separate instrument from competition policy.  I would like to conclude by saying that I am hopeful that we can get your support for the IMCO report in tomorrow’s vote and that this institution will send a strong message to the Commission on the measures to be included in the DSA.

name: Tiemo WÖLKEN
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Commissioner, in recent weeks the documentary "The social dilemma" has consistently been in the top ten most watched films on Netflix. The message of the film or the documentary is frightening and very powerful at the same time.  Social media platforms have long since ceased to be a simple communication tool, but huge profit machines that play a major role in shaping public discourse. They do this by not only deciding what information we receive, but also deciding which content can be displayed at all and which may not – unfortunately often also contrary to the law. However, I do not want the freedom of expression of users in Europe to be in the hands of private companies, which present themselves as auxiliary sheriffs and make decisions that are actually only allowed to be taken by courts. If we say that the law should apply both online and offline, then there must be an end to interference with freedom of expression through overblocking and arbitrary deletion by platforms. That is why the JURI report proposes to establish clear procedural rules for the notice-and-action system for dealing with illegal content. This is important because it creates legal certainty for the platforms on the one hand, but also creates legal certainty for users and respects their fundamental rights. In addition, our report calls for a strong European supervisory authority that can ensure compliance with the rules and, above all, has the necessary enforcement powers to ensure the necessary transparency. An online platform must not be a black box. Its actions must be transparent, well-founded and comprehensible, especially when it makes such important decisions about the freedom of expression of users.  And that brings me to a point that I am particularly proud of in our report, that we have proposed that we install a system that does not require prior checking of uploaded content. In fact, we explicitly require the Commission not to encourage platforms to use upload filters. Also, the voluntary use of technical aids by platforms must not result in content being scanned and blocked at the time of upload. And I think this is a huge success after last year's debate and a step towards an Internet without additional upload filters.  There is also content that is legal but can still cause great social damage. Such content as fake news, disinformation, hate speech and propaganda cannot be subject to the same rules as when dealing with illegal content, as such content is often below the taste limit, but is protected by freedom of expression. And the problem we have with such content is not so much that it exists at all, but that it spreads like wildfire through the Internet and is preferably flushed into users' timelines by platforms, because algorithms believe that attention-grabbing content is more important than democratic debate, for example. Thus, platforms can promise their actual customers – not us as users, but the advertisers – a particularly effective submission of targeted personalized advertising.  But if algorithms exploit human curiosity for attention-grabbing content for profit, and fake news, hatred and hate speech are the gift wrapping paper in which personalized advertising is packaged online, then we as legislators must step in and take action against this business model. That is why we are calling in the report for users to have more control over their content. They have to decide what content they see, and they have to decide whether they want to see targeted online ads at all. We must not allow user algorithms to be at the mercy of algorithms that erode our common social information base and jeopardise our democracy. If this is to be the price of Silicon Valley companies being able to make more profits with personalized advertising, then that price is clearly too high, and this business model has nothing to do with our digital single market. That is why I am strongly in favour of remaining unequivocally in the text of the Committee on Legal Affairs in tomorrow's vote, despite the split vote requested on advertising. The split vote on paragraph seventeen seeks to undermine protection against these very harmful business practices – and it is clear to us that this must not happen, the business interests of the advertising industry must not be allowed to be protected from the interests of the citizens.  Ladies and gentlemen, we are not yet at the forefront of the European Union's development of AI, but with the discussion we are having here today, we are a big step ahead of both China and Silicon Valley. In Europe, artificial intelligence and digital services must follow our principles, our values and our fundamental rights, not the other way around.

name: Kris PEETERS
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, online services are everywhere, from the way we inform ourselves to the way we keep in touch with friends; from the way we buy books and clothes to the way we travel; from the way we eat to the way we make a date. Some people born in a different time, like myself, might want to go back to how it was before, because it seems like a simpler time. But we can’t. We simply cannot put the genie back into the bottle. The online world with digital services, with artificial intelligence – it’s all here to stay. The future will be more digital, not less, and it brings incredible progress that we, as policymakers, should embrace. But... it also brings dangers that we cannot ignore anymore. Let us be honest with each other, colleagues. The EU has done more to regulate the online world than any other continent. Yet, even here, it is still the Wild West! Over the past decades, we have not followed up on illegal content and illegal activities online with the same rigour as we have illegal activities offline. We have not achieved any meaningful transparency over how algorithms push content to users on a massive scale. We have not grasped the impact of it on our democracies, our culture and our fundamental rights. Instead, we have focused on voluntary cooperation, which is good, but not good enough. Not nearly good enough. So as this European Parliament discusses these six reports on the Digital Services Act (DSA) and artificial intelligence (AI), I have one overarching message: these digital files matter a great deal more than many people think. We cannot leave this to the private sector without oversight and enforcement. We must keep this in the public debate as a priority and we must regulate, no matter how technical these files are. The difficult challenge before us is to find the balance between digital progress and respect for fundamental rights. As rapporteur for the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) DSA report, I’m raising a few issues right now. The value of lawmaking is the real change it effects. If we start off with conflicting regulations and directives that undermine each other instead of complementing each other, we have lost the battle before it starts. We must respect the scope of each digital file. Secondly, the fundamentals of the e-commerce Directive were great, but its greatest issue was transparency. We must improve and enforce meaningful transparency, and I call for a clear mandate from this Parliament. Thirdly, we all agree on the importance of notice and action mechanisms to remove illegal content online, but it places the burden almost entirely on users. We therefore should complement notice and action with clear and appropriate obligations to remove illegal content, and it’s the public authorities who should provide the funding to follow up on this. Finally, I would like of course personally to thank all the shadow rapporteurs and all my colleagues on the LIBE DSA report for their excellent cooperation.

name: Marcos ROS SEMPERE
text: deputy rapporteur. – Madam President, I will take the floor on behalf of my colleague and rapporteur on this report, Ibán García del Blanco, who cannot be here in the House today and who should be thanked for the immense work done. The framework of ethical principles applicable to artificial intelligence is the first legislative initiative report in the artificial intelligence package, drawn up in Parliament. The position of the European Parliament which we will adopt this week will undoubtedly be essential in future European legislation. The report is the result of lengthy and complex negotiations between all political groups, which were based on far-fluer positions, and also from the work done with the seven parliamentary committees that have issued opinions. On the part of the rapporteur, Ibán García del Blanco, I would like to thank you all for your work and your commitment to achieving totally new regulation, which puts Europe at the forefront of creating regulation that allows technological advances to become benefits for all.  The legislative report contains a motion for a Resolution with recommendations to the Commission and a proposal for a European Regulation laying down the ethical principles applicable to the development, implementation and use of artificial intelligence, robotics and related technologies in the Union.  Artificial intelligence is presented to us as a technology with the potential to change the world as we know it, offers great opportunities and carries great risks. Our proposal is a balance to, on the one hand, to ensure the trust and safety of citizens in new technologies and, on the other hand, to support innovation in Europe. It is a proposal that respects technological neutrality and provides an appropriate future framework to respond with solvency and responsibility to the speed of change.  Our report is based on the creation of a regulatory framework of ethical principles that is mandatory for software, algorithms and data included in artificial intelligence, robotics and related technologies that are developed, implemented or used in the European Union.  All technologies operating in Europe must respect this anthropocentric perspective. The human dignity, autonomy and security of citizens cannot be called into question and, likewise, we must ensure compliance with fundamental rights and the legality of the Union. Technologies that involve a violation of these principles will not be able to operate in Europe, no matter where they occur or whether they are supported or in the cloud.  Secondly, we have agreed on an approximation based on the risks they may present. Technologies that may have a significant risk of causing harm or harm ⸺that to citizens as well as society as a whole⸺, violating fundamental rights or breaking Union laws will be considered high risks. To assess these risks we have established objective criteria, taking into account the sector, the uses or purposes and the severity of the damages that may be caused. This definition is intended to avoid legal loopholes. It also includes an exhaustive list of sectors and uses that are considered high risk, such as education, health, employment and recruitment of workers, finances and lending, automatic vehicle transport, public administration decisions or environmental issues.  Where an application or technology is considered high risk, it must ensure compliance with a number of legal requirements and obligations: ensuring human control, strict security standards, transparency, explainability and accountability, data reliability, non-discrimination and bias removal in algorithms and the results of automatic decisions, with very strict privacy guarantees in the case of remote recognitions with biometric data and the requirement to apply the most stringent rigorous governance standards. In Parliament, we also want to ensure environmentally sustainable artificial intelligence with social responsibility, because ethical artificial intelligence is democratic, egalitarian, respects workers and intellectual property, cultural diversity and the right to digital illustration. That is why we call on the Member States and the Union to direct research investments to projects that offer a social or environmental benefit. To ensure the democratic development of technologies, both European and national authorities should have a dialogue with stakeholders, including civil society, trade unions, setting parameters and governance standards, as well as supporting SMEs and start-ups. In addition to establishing the principles, we must monitor compliance with these obligations. Our model strengthens European coordination and lists the tasks to be carried out, inter alia, to establish mandatory guidelines for the assessment of conformity with ethical principles.  Where proven, a European certificate is granted in accordance with ethical principles. This guarantee or seal of quality will be voluntary for non-high risk technologies.  Each Member State shall appoint an independent authority responsible for implementing those guidelines, granting the European certificate and continuously monitoring compliance with ethical principles, providing it with sufficient resources and resources.  The Commission should assess which existing or future agencies and agencies can perform these tasks.  With the rapporteur, in my group we believe that a European agency for artificial intelligence will add value in achieving a common objective, shared by all the members of the House: to make the European Union lead an ethical artificial intelligence in the world, to place human beings at the centre of their development and to guarantee our principles and values.

name: Stéphane SÉJOURNÉ
text: Madam President, since we are talking about artificial intelligence and new technologies, thank you very much to the European Parliament and also to the Paris office for giving parliamentarians the opportunity to intervene from the offices! Thank you also to the President of Parliament. Madam President, we are talking about artificial intelligence: it is present in our daily lives, with social networks of course, with everyday algorithms, and in our economy too, of course. By 2022, 42% of tasks will be performed by algorithms, compared to 29% today: this is an exponential measure. Two out of three companies already use artificial intelligence on a daily basis. Two reports have already been submitted on accountability and ethics. I would like to thank Mr Voss first of all for his important report, because it deals concretely with the question of responsibility, as well as how to regulate the major technologies of the future, such as the autonomous car. It also allows for a right that does not break down and to have legislation and jurisprudence that are precisely unified at European level. I would also like to thank Mr Garcia Del Blanco, who has also not been able to be with you, for his work on the question of ethics, which is a matter of trust first, and in this respect transparency is not an end in itself, it is a tool of trust. I will take the example of image recognition: used by smartphones, recognition is, when it works, a good tool, but there can be drifts, as when we see a number of police states use this technology. My report, Madam President, is also an element of protection. After the protection of ethics, after the protection of responsibility, there is also the protection of innovations, which must be protected via intellectual property. We recommend that the Commission review this issue and reset on it. Never before has the world had so many ideas, with 3.3 million patent applications filed last year, and it is constantly increasing. The question of this report is who owns the intellectual property rights to intellectual work entirely generated by artificial intelligence. My report, without wishing to discourage human creation, gives a number of recommendations. I'll name three. We recommend not recognizing legal personality to artificial intelligence. We also recommend distinguishing the creation that was aided by artificial intelligence from a creation that was entirely generated by artificial intelligence. There will also need to be a major data strategy. I know that Margrethe Vestager and Thierry Breton are very sensitive to these issues. This strategy is necessary, we need large data sets for an artificial intelligence system to develop and also develop ideas. I will end up, Madam President, with a topical point which may be outside the scope of my report, but which is also part of this joint debate on digital services legislation (DSA). The French news also shows us how much we will have to think collectively about data regulation: I am talking about the tragedy we experienced in France with the beheading of a teacher who had been lynched on social media for weeks. For my part, I believe that we must put an end to the self-regulation of social networks and an end to hateful content. We need to get out of the hypocrisy on this issue. Who can accept that Twitter accounts promote terrorism for weeks without anyone doing anything? In my opinion, no one! Who can accept such a hate spill on all networks, on Facebook? No one. Who can accept the public lynching of a teacher who was just doing his job? No one. Madam President, it is a question of taking responsibility, with our colleagues, with all the European representation, with the Commission and in its support. It is about our values, our European values, our values of democracy. It is a question of regulating social networks and going a little further than just the issue of illegal content by addressing that of harmful content. I think it is a good way to act. Thank you very much for allowing us to integrate this reflection from the Paris office and from other offices for other colleagues. I will speak again if I have to in the debate.

name: Axel VOSS
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Vice-President Vestager, I would like to thank the Rapporteur on the work she has First of all, my report is now about liability and artificial intelligence, and I would like to begin by thanking the shadow rapporteurs very warmly, because we have had a very cooperative spirit here that has taken us forward, but which ultimately also sends a strong signal, both to the Commission and to the Member States. Digitisation as a whole is, of course, extremely important and challenging for society, for the economy, but I believe that it is also about our economic survival. Artificial intelligence is of particular importance in this context and poses a particular challenge and is of strategic relevance to our overall economic development. We will only really be able to absorb competition if we actually get a digital single market, otherwise we will simply be too fragmented to face other regions of the world. That is why I believe that the Member States must also go into themselves here and sometimes go beyond their competences and say that this is for the good of all, if we also talk about civil liability accordingly. You cannot just block it and then say that is our competence. No, this is about a digital single market, about all of us making progress. Consequently, we are basically calling for a regulation in this regard, and we really mean this seriously, particularly with regard to this digital single market. What actually led us to do that? We want individuals to receive compensation as they do under normal national offences. But we also don't want him to explain whether it was the software, the hardware, the wrong operation or the wrong algorithms. We just want him to be compensated. We also want to comply with existing liability regulations from the member states. We do not want to prevent artificial intelligence and its system, and we want to move forward in a forward-looking way.  Why do we think this is important? It is now up to us to develop this. We therefore need a clear view of things, legal certainty, legal clarity, a fully harmonised framework, not fragmentation, in order to exclude the different applications in the internal market. We also want clarity – not only by the highest courts after five to eight years – and we want to fill legal gaps.  That is why, in the end, there is no over-regulation, so the whole thing is not a revolution, but merely the connection of correspondinghigh-risk artificial intelligence systems to what already exists, and we also consider this connection to the existing law to be reasonable. That is why we must keep in mind that, as the Committee on Legal Affairs and the Internal Affairs, we cannot at the moment offer a coherent system either, because we simply cannot take certain things into account, following internal regulations. The aim here is actually to limit ourselves to high-risk applications, because we think that only that actually makes sense to provide this with appropriate liability. Other risk AI systems are in any case subject to the normal legal consequences of liability.  Because of the legal clarity, we want to have a clear list of which AI system is covered, and we, as legislators, want to be flexible so that we can also quickly point out rapid changes by providing the Commission with delegated acts. In addition, non-material damages are also mentioned, and we ask the Commission to examine whether there is a need for harmonisation here too.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. – Madam President, the Internet is a vital part of our lives and our economy. Because of this, we all should want an Internet that reflects our European values, while being a fair single market for businesses to compete in. This is what the Renew Europe Group wants and this is what is in the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection (IMCO) report, and for this, I thank the rapporteur. Renew Europe wants any future European regulation to respect what makes the Internet great, which is the freedom to speak your mind, to upload your creations and to, at the click of a button, share new innovations and new business models which change the world. We don’t want to over-regulate. The reason why we have this Internet we love is because we set down very basic rules in Europe and then got out of the way. We let the Internet grow organically. We let innovation and start-ups run free, and here we are 20 years later.  Governments should not get in the way of a global system that is working well. Governments should especially not get in the way of the freedom of speech online. This must be equally true for the EU as a whole.  At the same time, a lot of things in the digital world have changed in 20 years – just look at where this debate is happening. One of these changes is the growth of Internet giants. The Renew Europe group is not against such companies that millions of users use and trust. Nevertheless, we must make sure they play fairly with other companies and take a greater role in social responsibility. We, however, don’t want to force actions where they are not needed – regulation for the sake of regulation. Artificial barriers to foreign companies and the creation of false European champions are not the answer to a strong digital single market in Europe. This is why we call on the Commission to keep this balanced approach as we work on the Digital Services Act and the Digital Market Act.

name: Alexandra GEESE
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. Madam President, Vice-President Vestager, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mrs Vestager, for the work she has The Internet was and is a place of freedom, especially in autocratic states, and preserving that freedom is our most important task. But today, the concern is huge: misinformation is spreading at breathtaking speed, hatred and hatred are displacing women and minorities from the public digital discourse, and this, too, threatens freedom of expression. But how has this happened in the last 20 years? Today, it is a few monopolistic companies that make a decisive decision about what people see on the Internet in the first place. That is why we now need new legislation on digital services and new rules for competition.  What are the most urgent tasks? First of all, we need to put an end to an advertising business model that spies on people and manipulates their behaviour. We must also seize this opportunity to put the financing of the quality press back on a safe footing, because we need it so urgently in times of uncertainty. Today, three-quarters of digital advertising revenue – in France and Germany, for example – goes to Google and Facebook. Secondly, online platforms must disclose the principles under which they prioritise contributions. We need to shed light on these platforms, and users must have the opportunity to design their timelines according to their own wishes.  Thirdly, we need very clear rules for dealing with illegal content, that is, detailed and binding notice-and-action procedures. Transparency and democratic control, then, are also our guiding values for artificial intelligence. Artificial intelligence must serve European priorities, and that is first and foremost the European Green Deal at the moment, because our most urgent task is still climate protection. But when it comes to people, we need strict rules, because we know that artificial intelligence is a good servant, but a bad gentleman. We know that artificial intelligence projects past imbalances, such as racism or the disadvantage of women, into the future and therefore anchors us in the past, and we do not want that.  Finally, we must effectively enforce European fundamental rights, including in the case of artificial intelligence, and this will only be possible with a European body that can represent the interests of European citizens on an equal footing with global digital companies.

name: Josianne CUTAJAR
text: Rapporteur għal opinjoni tal-Kumitat għat-Trasport u t-Turiżmu. – Tkellimna ħafna fl-aħħar xhur fuq kif l-Ewropa trid tikseb awtonomija teknoloġika. Ir-rapport li qed nidssdd llum huwa pass importanti f'din id-direzzjoni. Is-suq globali ddominat mill-ġganti itellef flower-kumpaniji żgħar Ewropej waqt li jimpatta ħażin flower-konsumaturi.  B'mod li nirrikonoxxu n-natura diġitali tal-pjattaformi jeħtieġ li nżidu r-responsabbiltajiet li għandhom iġorru. Biex nipproteġu aħjar flower-konsumatur jeħtieġ li l-pjattaformi diġitali jkunu mistennija jivverifikaw l-identità ta' dawk li jipprovdu s-servizz tagħhom. Mhux biss, imma neħtieġu protocol ħar għall-pjattaformi biex jieħdu azzjoni fuq kontenut illegali fl-ispazji tagħhom. It-tourist u l-passiġġieri jixraqilhom trattament tajjeb. Dan ifisser servizz trasparenti u li l-konsumatur ikun infurmat biżżejjed biex jagħmel l-aħjar għażliet għalih. Ikollna suq ġust biss jekk kulħadd igawdi mid-data li niġġeneraw il-ħin kollu.  Huma dawn l-elementi li neħtieġu għal suq inqas frammentat u iktar konsolidat li jipproteġi flower-aktar vulnerabbli u jħares id-drittijiet.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: rapporteur of the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. – Madam President, Commissioner, the development of computing, big data and algorithms has made artificial intelligence strategic today. But only people can ensure that values such as pluralism, solidarity and democracy vacute us against mistakes and abuses that can turn this opportunity into a pandemic of 'artificial negligence'. We need clear, simple, flexible and common legislation that does not harm the competitiveness of our entrepreneurs in the global market and avoid fragmentation, that controls the processes of generation and operation of these tools, detects risks and corrects dysfunctions through ongoing evaluation and ensures structured participation of users.  This global plan should encourage intense local action, focused on coordinating and better understanding technological capabilities, promoting talent and supporting intra-establishment and the creation of new companies. Thus, by bringing knowledge and value to the local industrial system, regions such as the Basque Country, recently identified as an example of innovation by President Von der Leyen, must help the Union gain global competitiveness. Artificial intelligence needs ethical principles to prevent biases in algorithms, clarify industrial and legal aspects, and establish formulas for determining and debugging civil liability arising from facts where the influence of artificial intelligence is key. This is a crucial aspect in the field of mobility. From the Committee on Transport and Tourism we are committed to artificial intelligence to offer integrated services, better adapted to users and greener. But we warn that without investment in infrastructure for data to be properly collected and circulated, technology will not suffice. The changes that are coming demand a holistic view of urban and intercity transport and innovation and training to consolidate the new trades that smart mobility already demands.

name: Petra KAMMEREVERT
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has The debates on the Digital Services Act so far have shown me that we have not yet sufficiently internalised what it actually means that the EU has been a legal entity of the UNESCO Convention for the Protection and Promotion of Cultural Diversity and Expressions for 15 years now. The random presence of many colorful videos on the net may be entertaining, but it is by no means the safeguarding of cultural diversity or even media diversity. Cultural and media diversity will only be ensured if we oblige all key actors to guarantee the discoverability of journalistic content and the content of cultural education beyond economic interests without ifs and buts.  This requires bold regulation that starts before large service providers are important or even gatekeepers. This requires special regulation, because media are not only an economic asset, but also a cultural asset and must therefore be treated differently from butter or screws.  It is not the variety of colourful videos, but the existence of credible and high-quality information that is easily accessible to everyone, that is the basic prerequisite for enabling a meaningful public debate in a digitised world that forms the foundation of a free, democratic society. Because this is so important, special regulations are needed, especially in the area of cultural and media diversity. And in a world where big data and algorithmic decisions are playing an increasingly important role, we are facing a paradox: for the intermediaries themselves, the processes of opinion-forming are becoming more and more transparent through data that is accessible to them. But the public knows less and less about the mechanisms and influences that shape political opinion formation.  You can see for yourself that the disclosure of algorithms alone will not be enough for this. There is a need for courageous and, above all, pre-designed protection of diversity and, above all, new policy initiatives to ensure independent quality journalism in the EU. I believe that we still have a great deal of work to do in this regard.

name: Patrick BREYER
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs. – Madam President, the digital age we live in today permeates our daily lives and even more so our children’s lives.  Can we accept that algorithms created by international corporations decide on what we can say and read online, what human rights defenders can say, what dissidents and whistle—blowers can publish?  Do you know that YouTube’s filters suppressed a parliamentary debate on torture because they confused it with violence online? Many constitutions ban ex—ante censorship. It is high time we take back control and do the same with censorship machines used by digital platforms.  Secondly, let’s tackle the predominant business model of surveillance capitalism. Major platforms are tracking our every click, everything we read and write online, to analyse our personalities, our likes, our weaknesses, our illnesses.  We cannot accept this permanent surveillance of users online, and therefore we need to make sure that we are not subject to pervasive tracking. Likewise, the right to anonymity is essential to safeguard our identity online and prevent abuses and data losses and sales. Finally, let’s address the gated communities on the internet. Let’s make sure consumers can choose which platform to use to ensure competition and to ensure interaction across platforms, to break the dependency and the user lock—in that is predominant on the internet. Let’s make sure we take back control of our digital lives. Let me add one aspect regarding the AI reports. There is some mention here of biometrics surveillance that has nothing to do with the report on AI and IPR protection. Let’s make sure that we do not confuse artificial intelligence with surveillance. This language on biometrics surveillance needs to be deleted.

name: Assita KANKO
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. – Madam President, we are in the midst of a global tech race. Technology should empower us all, but we see everyday how it can be deployed for malign purposes, from deep-fake videos undermining democracy to the challenge of fully autonomous weapon systems. The EU is a regulatory power, but we must also be a tech superpower, not only for regulation but also for promoting technology and supporting it. That means developing metadata skills and partnerships with like-minded allies. The only way to ensure ethical development of AI is for the world’s democracies to win the global tech race and set the global standards. If China comes first, our ethical frameworks will be nothing more than well-intentioned empty words, and that cannot be.

name: Marina KALJURAND
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. – Madam President, as the S&D shadow, first of all, I'd like to thank our rapporteur Kris Peeters and all the other shadows for the constructive work and I'd like to congratulate us all on a balanced and forward-looking report. This topic is very close to my heart. I come from Estonia, a country where we have had the privilege of enjoying the benefits of online services for almost 30 years and I will continue in Estonian. The COVID-19 crisis proved to the whole world what we have known about digital society in Estonia for nearly thirty years. We are used to the opportunities offered by digital services, and we know the challenges and risks that the use of digital services entails.  I am convinced that a functioning digital single market will bring economic and societal benefits to every person, to every Member State, to the European Union as a whole. And I am pleased that we have reached a review and modernisation of the regime governing digital services at European Union level. The e-commerce directive was adopted twenty years ago. It needs to be modernised. I look forward to the Commission's proposal for legislation on digital services and hope that it will take into account the proposals made in our report, which focus in particular on fundamental rights and data protection. I'll mention the most important of them. Digital services must be based on existing European Union legislation, including the General Data Protection Regulation and the ePrivacy Directive. A fair digital ecosystem must be ensured, which respects fundamental rights, in particular freedom of expression and information, and any discrimination must be ruled out. What is illegal outside the internet must also be illegal online and eliminated. Digital service providers, including online platforms, must be subject to clear and specific obligations to eliminate illegal content. Cooperation between service providers and national authorities needs to improve. The general supervisory obligation, which is laid down today in the e-commerce directive, must continue to be prohibited. In doing so, it should be stressed that today's automated means do not adequately analyse and understand online content, and that the final decision must remain with the people.  I am convinced that the digital services market cannot be complete and perfect without a european current digital ID. I hope that the Commission will speed up action to enforce the electronic identification regulation across the territory of the European Union, because the current pace cannot be satisfied. And I welcome the conclusions of october this year, which emphasise the need for the safe identification of persons through the European Union-based framework. I would also like to emphasise aspects of cyber security, both from the consumer point of view of the consumer and from the point of view of the provision of services. We all need training, we all need a competent consumer.  Ladies and gentlemen, I call on all of you to vote in favour of all three reports.

name: Marina KALJURAND
text: Executive Vice—President of the Commission. – Madam President, I think it is kind of strange: we are few here because this is a digital debate, and yet the energy and the enthusiasm is to be felt. I think that comes from the fact that the work done is truly impressive, because it’s work that has involved so many colleagues in this assembly, so many colleagues who have done the effort to study the subjects, to form opinions and to discuss. Even though it will be, I think, a truly amazing debate today, it will in no way do justice to what has gone before this debate, because it is truly a thing that includes the entire Parliament. This is also why it’s a bit unfair to start thanking some rapporteurs and leaders in this, but I would say to Alex Saliba, Tiemo Wölken and Kris Peeters that this is outstanding work.  We will respond to your initiatives with two legislative proposals: the Digital Services Act and the Digital Markets Act, and this will reflect ideas. Fundamentally we share the same goals. I think that is most obvious. We want to better protect citizens when they use the internet, whether that is in protection against illegal goods, services, content online. As it was put, we need to make sure that as we feel safe offline we should feel safe online.  Also, to better secure the freedom of expression online. This of course, as you have heard already, is a tricky balance to strike. To achieve this, we need to lay down a solid and impactful EU—wide accountability framework. Obviously that has to come with enforcement, because words alone will not do it; then it would be just window dressing. The balance we will have to strike here is of course that we will have to say to some of the gatekeepers, the largest platforms, that things will change.  Europe is open and we will do this in full compliance with our international obligations, also because we would want to work with the rest of the world to set new standards. In order to do so, we intend to break down legal barriers in the internal market and combat unfair practices by gatekeeper platforms. This will help European innovators, small businesses, to scale, to grow, to be able to compete for our attention, to compete for our business.  With the Digital Services Act I think two things have stood the test of time: no general monitoring of user content is one; and, second, a well—balanced system of liability, and the internal market as the core.  But things have changed, so obviously we also need to set out in law the responsibilities that platforms must have in relation to their role as societal and economic impactors, as they are. This is one of the reasons why we’re working on this Digital Markets Act in parallel with the Digital Services Act. This regulation will specifically target large digital gatekeepers defined by objective criteria, setting out a clear list of ‘dos and don’ts’ in full compliance again, of course, with international obligations. It will also provide for a market investigation framework to address digital markets that may be prone to market failure and prone to the creation of new gatekeepers.  On artificial intelligence, let me thank also MEP Ibán García Del Blanco for the intense work. I really welcome Parliament’s contribution here. This is ground—breaking, this has not been done before. We share the same ambition to create a sound and future—proof legal framework for trustworthy artificial intelligence in Europe so that people can benefit from AI—driven products and services that are safe and that respect European fundamental rights and values. For this we need an AI framework that creates new opportunities for European businesses to innovate, to scale up. We ought to be the global hub for AI Made in Europe and set the global standard for trustworthy AI. We want to fully leverage the potential of AI while mitigating associated risks, and I think we all recognise that this is the balance. We will be discussing this back and forth and back and forth, because it is indeed a balance to be struck as not every AI implies a risk. High—risk applications of AI should be put under intense scrutiny. However, we should not define high—risk AI so broadly that it creates legal uncertainty and disproportionately overburdens businesses or hampers innovation. We need to form a framework that is future—proof, and I expect that we will engage in this very intensely because it is indeed a balance.  We also welcome the report for dealing with liability for AI, and here Axel Voss has done outstanding work. It’s very impressive, and we agree that the current liability rules are challenged by AI characteristics. Our institutions also agree on the objective for liability aiming for the same level of protection for victims of AI—related damages, and victims of damages of other technologies. I think that is a very sound and straightforward principle. For what concerns the Product Liability Directive, the Commission appreciates the Parliament report. We will carefully consider it and then we will discuss. On the Parliament report on intellectual property (IP) rights, I think that shows the pivotal role of IP rights for the EU to become a leader in artificial intelligence. Without this, it will not happen, and we want to thank also MEP Stéphane Séjourné for his excellent work. We need an EU IP framework that enables innovations in the field of AI technologies. Companies in the European Union, must be able to efficiently protect but also to share their inventions in the field of AI technologies. That is what will create excellence in artificial intelligence. Thank you again also for this ground—breaking work.  Last, but not least, I think this will be an amazing debate. We have started it, I think, already in the best possible manner. One of the delights is to see how there is convergence between the different reports, between the thinking of the Commission and what Parliament is proposing here. I think that is very strong because that shows citizens that what we want to create is a society where technology serves humans, where humans are empowered, where humans are in control. We don’t want a society where people feel estranged, feel that there is the risk that some machine will take some decision in complete transparency without knowing if their rights are actually being fulfilled. We have one generation to do this. This is now, it is happening, and I do hope that you will recognise many of these valuable points in what we suggest. I’m looking forward not only to the debate today, not only to the proposals, but also to the debate that we will have to make sure that we get a strong European regulatory framework that can actually be enforced in real life.

name: Lina GÁLVEZ MUÑOZ
text: drafts member of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. – Madam President, as rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs on the report on the ethical aspects of artificial intelligence, prepared by Ibán García del Blanco in the Committee on Legal Affairs, I would like to underline the significance that this dossier has for the dignity and rights of workers.  The greater flexibility or efficiency that the use of these technologies may bring cannot be synonymous with more sophisticated forms of exploitation or supervision of workers. As a result, the law, our legislative framework, must move forward with regulations that protect workers from monitoring and metric mechanisms that violate their privacy, reputation or promotion possibilities or stay in their workplace.  We must ensure that worker data belongs to workers, even when the employment relationship is over. The development of this technology should be free from discriminatory biases and the reproduction of gender, race, class or sexual preference stereotypes. This initiative is simply a first step and should be followed by specific legislation on labour issues.

name: Adam BIELAN
text: draft opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The European Union's efforts to deepen the single market for digital services, which will enhance Europe's digital sovereignty and competitiveness, should be a priority for us , especially now, after the experience of the coronavirus epidemic, one of the most important tasks for this House.  I therefore welcome the Commission's commitments and progress in introducing a harmonised approach to the obligations of digital service providers, including online intermediaries, in order to avoid the partitioning of the internal market and inconsistent enforcement. However, when introducing the new rules, we must bear in mind that burdening small and medium-sized enterprises with unnecessary new obligations can hamper their development and prevent them from gaining market position.  The Digital Services Code must also respect the fundamental rights of users and consumers, such as privacy and non-discrimination, and, above all, must not undermine freedom of expression, the great prey of the internet. I would also like to stress the importance of respecting different national traditions so that, in the fight against illegal content, we do not impose the same rules throughout Europe, for example in the case of controversial statements. I am therefore in favour of maintaining the ban on the general obligation to monitor content, and I believe that supervision of the content moderation system should be ensured so that it does not become a censorship tool for private companies.  The Digital Services Code can only interfere with illegal content, there can be no compromises in defending freedom of expression.

name: Svenja HAHN
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Artificial intelligence is everyday life for us. For example, when our music streaming app suggests new songs based on our listening habits. Other areas may be less commonplace for most of us, but they have the potential to change products, industries, and even our entire lives – in medicine, mobility, or agriculture. The EU has now set itself the goal of creating a single set of rules. This is pioneering work, and it must also be said that it offers a real economic and social opportunity and can become a great locational advantage. There are three points that we must pay particular attention to: firstly, we must encourage innovation rather than slow down. We should remain open to technology in any form of regulation and rely on unbureaucratic rules.  Secondly, civil rights are non-negotiable. The protection of fundamental rights is high on my agenda. There must be no mass monitoring through automatic facial recognition, nor must there be any obligation to upload filters. Thirdly, harmonisation in the internal market. We are only raising the opportunity of artificial intelligence for people and the economy with uniform rules for the entire internal market. This creates maximum legal certainty for businesses and consumers. But we don't have to reinvent the wheel for that. In many areas, we already have existing rules, for example on the issue of liability, on the issue of intellectual property. But we need to look closely: in what points do we perhaps need updates that correspond to the characteristics of artificial intelligence? Our aim must be to set a framework that is smart, open to technology and sustainable and based on ethical principles and European fundamental values. Then we can do it, then the European Union can make it to the top of the world, to the top of the world in innovation.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. – Mr President, the desire to build machines that replace human activities has existed for centuries. What was once considered the future is now part of our daily life with the name of artificial intelligence. Artificial intelligence is therefore a data-based model and this data is the main catalyst for innovation in today's digital and technological age.  With regard to transport, whether in automated vehicles, infrastructure or intelligent traffic management solutions for goods or, simply, for mobility, the levels of automation and artificial intelligence, as well as different, are well developed in this sector compared to other sectors.  Our role as co-legislators is to ensure that the Union creates common principles adapted to this reality, that within the framework of civil liability in Europe the same levels of consumer protection are guaranteed when it comes to the use of artificial intelligence in the physical or virtual space, ensuring confidence in these systems, supporting technological innovation without creating unnecessary bureaucracies to the business fabric that it intends to innovate. I believe that this is why we must and must all work.

name: Andor DELI
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. – Madam President, as the draftsperson for the Committee on Transport and Tourism opinion on Intellectual property (IP), I can say that the role of AI in these sectors will be crucial.  Traffic safety and security in all transport modes, automated driving, navigation, car manufacturing, the hostility sector – these need access not only to big data but also to standard-essential patents (SEP) and other intellectual property under equal and fair conditions throughout the EU internal market.  But with AI it became obvious that intellectual property protection strategies of the past cannot work. We must develop flexible copyright, patent, trademark design protection and even trade secret rules that will accommodate all these new aspects.  Europe needs these legal instruments fast. We need the IP and AI framework that incentivises innovation and protects Europe’s pole position in car manufacturing and in tourism, for example. There is no time to waste, so I am urging the Commission to act as fast as possible.

name: Łukasz KOHUT
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. – Madam President , while the advantages of AI for society as a whole are indisputable, we need to make sure that everyone benefits from it. Digital social exclusion: without the know-how on the ever-progressing digital tools, many of our citizens will not be able to benefit from them, especially senior citizens. But, not only that, they might also be excluded from certain public spaces completely, if the only way to participate is digitally and they have no such competence.  Education is key. We need custom-tailored digital education at all levels. Education is also paramount for fighting AI-related conspiracy theories, which feed the agenda of those who want to politically cash in on people’s fears. Let me just mention 5G or chemtrails conspiracies. So, once again, education is essential for this process to be successful.

name: Pablo ARIAS ECHEVERRÍA
text: PPE Group. – Madam President, Vice-President Vestager. First of all, I wanted to thank the rapporteur, Mr Saliba, and all the shadow rapporteurs for the effort and spirit of collaboration to reach consensus during the negotiations on this report. I believe that we have all done a good job and reached agreements which send a clear message to the Commission on how the Digital Services Act should be addressed. The Digital Services Act should aim to create a safer, fairer and more transparent digital single market for all: citizens, consumers and businesses, especially our SMEs. To this end, it is important to develop balanced legislation tailored to the challenges that come to us from the constant evolution of the digital field. The European Commission has established three pillars on which to cement its strategy: the digital pillar, the environmental pillar ⸺or the Green Pact⸺ and the European way of life. This report by the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection is, by its nature, based on the digital field. We also reflect the importance of the Green Pact: e-commerce must take into account the environmental impact and act accordingly, provided that its practice does not burden the competitiveness of our companies. Throughout its history, our values and way of life have made us different from the rest of the world. It has made us an example to follow in many areas. We're neither Chinese nor Americans. Here we have a high consideration of our privacy and data protection, we do not give them to governments or companies in any way. We care about transparency, we want to know why, how and why our data is collected and who stays it. Every foreign company operating here must comply with our way of doing things.  In short, we need to find our own way of regulating the digital ecosystem, finding a balance which, in the long run, will undoubtedly be a competitive advantage for our SMEs, our citizens and in general for the European Union. That is why I think it is important to collect the European way of life. Without this third pillar, the report is incomplete. The amendment I table on behalf of my group goes in this direction, it is not against anyone; rather, on the contrary, it is in favour of each and every European and aims to reflect the values that un bring us together. Only by being faithful to them will we become a relevant player in the global digital career.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: for the S&D Group. Thank you, Madam President, and Commissioner!  We are having a very wide debate today with a wide range of aspects around digitisation and artificial intelligence, and I think it is very useful. However, with my speaking time today, I will give priority to looking at what is about the internal market and consumer protection. My message today to the Commission is very brief: it is that in future legislation we must ensure that what is illegal offline also continues to be illegal online. That is why it is also great to hear that the Commissioner has already indicated that it is also the approach of the Commission with the forthcoming legislation that is really important. However, we have seen numerous examples of dangerous baby rangers, toxic toy figurines, useless face masks, etc. – things that are being sold today online that are dangerous to consumers, something we would not accept lay on the shelves of physical stores. It is important to get something done about it, even when we have the e-commerce directive revised. In fact, we must ensure that consumer safety is at the forefront, even when we shop online, and that is why I am also pleased that the report we have produced in the IMCO attaches particular importance to this. Consumers must be as safe when shopping online as when shopping offline.  It is also important – and we are also sending a signal about this in the report – that companies that want to sell goods to European consumers, even if they come outside Europe – that is, businesses – must comply with European rules. If they want to benefit from the European market, then they must comply with it and we must ensure that it can happen. And i also think it is important to stress that consumer information is also a key issue when people shop and act online. We must ensure that companies inform consumers if a product is removed from their platform. So what is happening offline in the general market today must in fact also be something we transfer to online companies in the future. In this way, we can ensure that consumers can be safe, and I look forward to the Commission also taking it into account in future legislation.

name: Karen MELCHIOR
text: renew group. Thank you, Madam President, and Commissioner! Ladies and gentlemen! I am speaking to you from the House of the European Parliament here in Copenhagen. I would first like to ask you: do you remember the good old days as far back as 2010, when we still believed that the new and fantastic Internet itself would open up and democratise public debate, allow everyone to speak up, enable subjugated peoples to organise and overthrow dictators. I remember those days. A dream of an open internet for an open and free world. But unfortunately it didn't stay that way. We were wrong!  Much of the public debate has shifted to the online platforms, and this has given them a huge impact on our democracy – and unfortunately probably not for the better. We've seen how the platform's business model has fertilized the ground for conspiracy theories and polarization, because it's exactly the type of content that creates interaction and makes you stay just a little longer. It is not a business model that has our public debate and the well-being of democracy in mind. That is why we need to legislate and make demands on the platforms. Firstly, platforms must be transparent and open to community control. Platforms shall have rules and continuously evaluate their content guidelines and engage in a dialogue on them. Secondly, platforms should not become censorship machines with the use of upload filters. The removal of illegal content must be carried out after a transparent process and with human control, with the exception, of course, of clearly illegal material such as calls for terrorism. Thirdly and finally, the responsibility for settling disputes between users and platforms must not lie with the platforms themselves. We don't put the fox to guard geese either! Online platforms have given us countless opportunities, but we need to address the challenges they face and tackle the challenges right. And that is exactly what the Committee on Legal Affairs' report is about. That is why we must dare to demand the platforms with the greatest power. As Pippi Longstocking would have said: when you are extra large, you have an extra obligation to be fair to others. I hope the Commission will listen and choose to follow our recommendations, because then Europeans will be one step closer to a more free and more open Internet. Thanks for the word!

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Madam President, artificial intelligence is an opportunity to seize because it will improve the efficiency of most human activities. It is also a great source of jobs and economic development, especially for start-ups and small and medium-sized enterprises. However, we must be vigilant, as it can also be a danger. It is to deal with this that the three reports Voss, Garcia Del Blanco and Séjourné were written. Overall, these three reports have achieved their objective by requiring that artificial intelligence always remain under human control to avoid possible liberticidal excesses. I particularly agree with the Voss report, which has the merit of avoiding excessive centralisation by asking that the damage caused by artificial intelligence be entrusted to national liability regimes for misconduct. It is rightly only for high-risk artificial intelligence systems that he advocates a new liability regime based on the obligation on their deployer to take out liability insurance, in order to guarantee their victims compensation. However, not everything is perfect and I regret in particular that some reports continue to consider the creation of a new European agency dedicated to artificial intelligence. From my point of view, there are already too many agencies. I also regret that the report Garcia Del Blanco envisages the use of artificial intelligence to censor hate speech and false information: these are too vague incriminations that will open the way to abuses against freedom of expression. They should be clarified, for example by clearing the offence of inciting Islamist terrorism. Finally, with regard to the report on digital services, I agree with its main guidelines, in particular the idea that the legality of content generated by their users should be determined by a national judicial authority and not by a private commercial entity. I also support the principle of respect for the freedom of expression of platform users, as well as the desire to combat the most intrusive forms of targeted advertising. In the end, I am pleased to have contributed to these four reports and thank the rapporteurs for accepting some of my suggestions.

name: Sergey LAGODINSKY
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The federal government has just unveiled a chat bot that would provide guidance for all of us in these difficult Covid times – an example of small-scale artificial intelligence. I just tried the bot and found one thing: normal human-like communication is not possible away from keyword—bingo. A chat bot of the Federal Government is of course not a reflection of the breathtaking developments we are facing, but it clearly shows one thing: there can be no AI without humans as creators, but also without people as end-users. Our artificial intelligence strategies must be thought of human-centered. And with these reports, we are taking the first real step in this direction. We establish human responsibility for AI. But we also write: responsibility for people. Intelligence may be artificial, but only with real, non-artificial fundamental rights can we make progress. That is why we warmly welcome the fact that the report on ethics is not just about philosophising on abstract ethical principles, but also a basis for binding European rules and fundamental rights.  Where algorithms cause damage – and we welcome this in the other report – it should not only be about property that is protected, but also about personal rights, about human dignity, about equality. If humans don't understand the federal government's chat bot, then the technology has failed. If humans are discriminated against by algorithms, then technology has failed. If artificial intelligence changes human habitat to the point of being unrecognizable and destroys our climate, then technology has failed. And this is not an appeal for pessimism, but for the optimism of progress. That is the most important thing for us.  After all, AI should not be thought of without green accounting. Of course, we need AI for our green transformation, but we cannot imagine it without looking at the damage of artificial intelligence. In Frankfurt alone, 20% of energy costs are generated by data centers. Internet consumes more CO2 in Germany than air traffic. We need to change that, we need to put that into the green accounting of AI – that is the only way forward. No AI technology without fundamental rights and without environmental protection.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. Honourable Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. Creating regulations in the area of new technologies is a race against time. Innovative systems that eerily meet standard definitions raise high hopes, but also numerous social concerns. Therefore, man, his dignity and rights must always be at the heart of digital transformation. It cannot be regarded as an unconscious, passive user or, worse, solely as a data source.  It will only be possible to fully exploit the potential of the digital revolution if we properly and transparently define the opportunities and risks of fully automating many areas of our lives. However, no technology is reliable. It is necessary to amend existing rules in areas such as the enforcement of liability for accidents and failures caused by AI-based systems. The redress and redress process must be transparent and the identification of the person responsible for the payment of compensation must not be a problem.  Obligations in this regard should be adequately integrated into the ability of manufacturers, operators and users of AI-based systems to control risks. This is very important in the development of appropriate insurance products, for example for autonomous vehicles. I am convinced that the Voss report defines challenges in this area well and suggests appropriate legal solutions. I hope that the Commission will agree with our recommendation.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, what is at stake in these various texts that we are discussing this evening? The question is: can we regain control over our digital lives? And is it possible, is it possible to invent a European model that is different from that of the United States, where we really notice the pursuit of profit at all costs, and which is also different from the Chinese model, where we see that technology is put at the service of mass surveillance for the dictatorship to continue? I think it is possible, if you are respectful of a number of fundamental principles, that you are able to set limits and set a framework. There are at least two points on which I think we can go further. The first is facial recognition. I share the doubts expressed by the many human rights organizations, which have warned of the use of artificial intelligence-driven video surveillance, which will totally disproportionately limit the possibilities of anonymous movement and which constitutes an unbearable intrusion into privacy with, in addition, risks, because AI is unable to avoid misidentification based on gender, age or ethnicity. This is a real problem and we need a European moratorium on video surveillance or, in any case, on facial recognition. The second point is consumer protection. Intellectual property must be respected, which is not the case today. Platforms like Amazon or Alibaba market counterfeit products. Almost two thirds of the products today, according to the European Consumers' Bureau, are illegal products. And there, Europe must crack down, because it is not up to the platforms to determine what is allowed and what is not. Finally, let me, because I speak from Paris, to tell you that it is absolutely necessary that the rights of citizens, respect for dignity and respect for human rights be ensured by the platforms, so that we escape the outpouring of digital hatred that led, the day before yesterday in France, to this abominable murder of a teacher who was really being pursued by a fatwa. It is also part of the debate on the recovery of our digital sovereignty and respect for the rights of European citizens.

name: Sabrina PIGNEDOLI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by thanking the rapporteurs for their great work. The starting point is, quite rightly, an ethical reflection which must give rise to appropriate laws. We cannot allow the ethical threshold of IA systems to fall below the human threshold. Artificial intelligence will pose many challenges. One scenario to be assessed is its misuse by criminal and terrorist organisations. There is a risk that the software that manages THE IS will be sabotaged or tampered with.  It would be naïve to think that cybercrime and cyber terrorism will not make a quantum leap as artificial intelligence systems evolve. Theft and smuggling of data, hacking, industrial copyright infringement, sabotage and hostage-taking of IA systems. We're not talking about science fiction, it's already happened. While we need to protect the patents that run the systems, it will be necessary to make these systems accessible to those conducting investigations, such as magistrates and police forces. It has already been seen in the past that companies holding encryption systems have obstructed or even refused access to those investigating terrorist groups and criminal organisations. I therefore want the Commission's text on the ethical aspects of IA to strike the right balance between system transparency, citizens' right to privacy, investigative needs to combat criminal organisations and copyright protection.

name: Geoffroy DIDIER
text: Mr President, since the savage murder of a French teacher, Samuel Paty, who was killed for doing only his job, it is not only France that is crying, it is the freedom-loving heart of every individual who bleeds. On Friday, the values of our European civilization were stabbed. Islamist individuals allowed the crime by revealing the teacher's name and address on social media. A Facebook account can become a lethal weapon. GAFA can no longer look elsewhere and wash their hands of it. Europe is the right scale to compel GAFA. I therefore refer three concrete measures to the European Commission. I propose that social accounts collect, every time an account is opened, a copy of the card of the holder's identity card. I believe in the possibility of using pseudonyms on the internet, but the person must be identifiable in the event of a violation of the law. I propose that each social network be forced to post on its home page a link to an online pre-complaint, where appropriate, to create a real capacity to respond to victims. Finally, I propose a new status for social networks because it is indecent for them to take refuge behind their hosting status in order, in fact, to absolve themselves of their responsibility. Tomorrow, with this new status, they can be considered complicit under the law in case of inertia or refusal to cooperate. The time for small candles and big speeches is over. What I am proposing is a European offensive against hate on the internet. We will not give life to Samuel Paty, but action is no longer an option, otherwise we will disappear.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: Mr President, our debate on the texts that foreshadow the digital services legislation (DSA) is taking place in a very particular context today, following the Islamist terrorist attack in France on Friday.  The freedom of expression defended by this college professor has earned him an atrocious killing organized by obscurantists. Social networks clearly played a fundamental role in the attack, as calls for hatred flourished there.
