Of course, harmful content and incitement to hatred on the Internet are not exactly our subject today, but how can we not have in mind this highly sensitive issue of the tools we have - or not - to defend fundamental freedoms while fighting criminals? Today, the texts deal with the digital services act. They set out unprecedented avenues for improvement to fill the current gaps in the online environment and establish a safer internet for its users. I note in particular the principle that what is illegal offline must also be illegal online, but also a binding mechanism of notification and action to combat illegal content online, while protecting the fundamental rights of users. My colleague Alex Agius Saliba's text aims to ensure better protection for online consumers by making online marketplaces more responsible. They will have to reveal the identity of their sellers, cover all entities that offer services and products to consumers, including when they are established outside the EU. They will have to remove products identified as illegal but also those identified as dangerous within 48 hours of notification, and inform consumers of any safety concerns. This is a much needed first step in view of the problems encountered, especially in the context of the current health crisis.

name: Liesje SCHREINEMACHER
text: – Mr President, sometimes you are looking for a new charger or a present for your birthday nephew. And then you come across online stuff at such low prices that you wonder how this can be so cheap. It's almost too good to be true. And it is! More than two thirds of products purchased on foreign online marketplaces are illegal or do not meet European security requirements. Their producers are usually not established within the EU, so consumers also have to go abroad with their complaint. And now that we work, learn and shop online, e-commerce in Europe is growing fast. That is good, but it is important that people can cope with the quality and safety of their products, especially since our European marketplaces and producers – with an exception – do follow the rules. I am therefore pleased that the European rules on online services are being revised so that consumers are better protected and our businesses do not lag behind. This also means that if you are active in the EU, you should have a point of contact in the EU when products or services do not meet European standards. In short, foreign companies also have to abide by our rules in our market. The corona crisis has also seen the potential of new technologies. For example, artificial intelligence helps doctors in the search for a vaccine and monitoring patients. If we want to use AI on a larger scale, trust from people and companies is crucial. Clear and transparent rules can help.  Fortunately, AI is not new and is already regulated by different laws. I therefore call for the introduction of new rules to ensure that they are proportionate to the impact of the application. Because a smart thermostat for heating in the home is not comparable to an algorithm that spreads fake news through social media. The digital market is an international market and, as far as I am concerned, our developers must be given the opportunity to fulfil our European ambitions.

name: Alessandra BASSO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Milan office for this link. The DSA should strengthen the system of accountability and security of Internet platforms for online services and markets and consumer protection, including the possibility of more rigorously regulating advertisements based on the study of behaviour, favouring less intrusive forms that do not require wide user traceability with respect to the content it displays. The measure to be voted on also calls for the DSA package to include a proposal that imposes ex ante obligations on large platforms that have a gatekeeper role. The aim is to prevent monopolies and to open up the market to new operators.  Furthermore, in the final text, there is an explicit reference to the obligation to use the opt-in tool also for political advertising. This may be useful in the case of advertising of products or services, but political advertising is neither a service nor a product and each Member State has its own specific legislation in the field of political advertising, so this reference is unacceptable to us.  Another point at dispute was the idea of the creation of a new European supervisory agency with investigative and enforcement powers. Fortunately, the compromise has led to the deletion of the initial proposal, but there is still a strong centralisation of the EU's supervisory and control system to the detriment of the sovereignty of individual states, which must remain intact. I also believe that the reference to e-speech, disinformation and fake news has been mis contextualised.

name: Marcel KOLAJA
text: – Mr President, I’d like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Saliba, for his work on the Committee on Internal Market and Consumer Protection (IMCO) report on the Digital Services Act (DSA) report, that gives clear political guidance on the Digital Services Act. With this report, Parliament calls for an active, unified notice and action system, while insisting that the final decision about the illegality of content remains with the courts. This also means that there will be safeguards against notices in bad faith. People will also have the possibility to better understand the reasons why their content was removed and contest removals in an out—of—court dispute settlement mechanism. At the same time, Parliament calls for interoperability rules that can help SMEs, start—ups or volunteer projects to provide alternatives to dominant platforms. However, transparency on removals, the possibility to contest removals and the possibility to choose alternative services is not enough because, if at the same time we encourage online platforms to use automated filters, we cannot ensure that completely legal speech doesn’t get systematically removed. The internet needs to remain a place where people can share time—sensitive information, have an open public debate or promote their products at the time of their choice, and this cannot be guaranteed with automated filters in place. We ask the Commission to take these points into account in the upcoming legislation. I apologise that I cannot stay longer for the debate because of other commitments I have.

name: Eugen JURZYCA
text: – Mr President, the e-Commerce Directive has been in force for 20 years, so many principles seem to have proved their case. Nevertheless, let us discuss which new European rules are needed from online marketplaces to disinformation. We often talk about the benefits of consumer protection, but we will not say what costs will be incurred by the consumer. For example, banning targeted advertising sounds great. But what impact will this have on the consumer? Some analyses argue that publishers' revenues will fall by more than 50% when targeted advertising is banned. It follows to me that not only services that are quasi-free today will be paid for, but also various other services can become more expensive. We must also know, with each proposal, what costs will be incurred by the consumer. It is therefore good that the report has succeeded in including rules to be adopted in view of the overall impact on consumer welfare. If we stick to this rule, I believe that we will help not only the consumer, but also the entire European digital market.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: – Mr President, I am glad that we are talking here about a subject that will play such an important part in the shape of the future world and Europe – artificial intelligence. The penetration of AI systems into manufacturing, services and all sectors of the economy is an integral part of Industrial Revolution 4.0, which will have major and broad-scale impacts. Ultimately, it will not be a technological change, but a complex transformation of cyber-physical-social. The development of artificial intelligence will have an impact on society as a whole and on all parts of our lives.  Artificial intelligence is not only a robot, as we might imagine based on karel Čapek's game and science fiction, but also software – simply an algorithm, which is often not completely obvious and can cause credibility problems. In doing so, it is essential that the systems used in Europe enjoy well-deserved credibility, also on the basis of respect for the principle of legality and regulations and ethical principles.  It has certainly been said many times today, and it will still be said that we must strike a balance – we must have clear rules, but we must not destroy the chances of European firms in the market with excessive restrictions. Of course, this approach can be partially agreed with. I also prefer that we use European systems and technologies in Europe and become notional champions on the world market. However, this must never happen at the expense of protecting European consumers. I believe that it is necessary for AI systems to be developed, implemented and used in the European Union only if they respect ethical principles relating to respect for human autonomy, harm prevention, justice and explainability.  The Fourth Industrial Revolution does not give us easy challenges, but we need to deal with them as soon as possible. Indeed, every opportunity is also a potential threat, and the stakes are high indeed.

name: Clara PONSATÍ OBIOLS
text: – Mr President, last July, the Guardian reported that many Catalan politicians, among them collaborators of MEP Carles Puigdemont i Casamajó, are being spied on illegally through Pegasus, a software that operates through WhatsApp and sells only to governments. Since the confirmation that the Spanish Government uses Pegasus to illegally spy on political opponents, there has been no judicial investigation and no one has resigned over this scandal. After all, in Spain, using illegal means, including censorship of web pages, is a routine practice to prosecute Catalan dissidents. What did the European Commission have to say about this scandal? Nothing. They feel they have the right to preach about fundamental rights all over the world: in Russia, in Belarus and even in the US, but when the abuse happens inside the EU, they selectively use the internal matter mantra and when it applies to Spain violating laws, the Commission is embarrassingly blind. The Digital Services Act must prevent companies and governments that collude to store data illegally and must also punish Member States that abuse digital technology against citizens.

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: Mr President, Madam Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has First of all, I would like to congratulate the rapporteurs on the various reports we are discussing today. And, in essence, Mr President, there is one thing at stake: it is about companies in Europe being able to work in a practical and simple way, and that we are creating a fair market in Europe where European suppliers as well as non-European suppliers compete properly with each other. The first principle is the easiest way to make this clear. As Our Colleague Kris Peeters has said before, what is illegal – what has been decided politically, that it is illegal – must also be illegal on the Internet. The decision as to what is illegal is made by politicians – they cannot make the platform. Enforcing this will be a crucial issue that we want to address with the Digital Services Act.  Secondly, Mr President, we are, of course, united in all our reports, we are opposed to general control of users on platforms. Freedom is a core principle of the European Way of Life, which we in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats defended with particular emphasis.  Thirdly, ladies and gentlemen, fair markets. The fight against oligopolies or monopolies is a core principle of the social market economy, which has unfortunately fallen into a bit of a mess in the digital environment. Defending this will be the task of the European Parliament, to which we are committed to these reports. That is why, Mr President, I hope that the report by the Committee on the Internal Market, like that of the other Members, will receive a broad majority tomorrow.

name: Maria-Manuel LEITÃO-MARQUES
text: – Mr President, artificial intelligence is a fashionable word. Some marvel at their powers, others are terrified. The truth is that it can serve both for the diagnosis of a complex cancer, to predict diabetes, and that these same data allow discriminatory selection by private companies, for example, insurers.  Which of these two extremes will proliferate depends on our ability to find the right regulation which, without halting innovation, gives citizens the necessary confidence. This Parliament has today made its contribution to advocating an ethical approach by design to artificial intelligence. We want to ensure that your applications are people-centric and contribute to the good of humanity. However, ethics is no longer sufficient and we are also discussing other aspects of regulation today, from certification to accountability, to ensure that any damage to artificial intelligence is mitigated and compensated, standards and harmonisation in order to have a single market for digital services in place.  In a world of superpowers that use technology as an instrument of strategic power, Europe cannot retreat, Commissioner, and watch the wave of artificial intelligence pass.  Parliament is here to ensure that we will do as the Union always does: it develops cutting-edge innovation, but with respect for our basic values and consumer rights.

name: Moritz KÖRNER
text: Mr President, Madam Vice-President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her work and for the work she has Today, we are discussing the Digital Services Act and want to set new rules for digitalization. We want to protect freedom on the Internet, take advantage of opportunities, innovate, but also address negative effects such as hate speech and fake news.  I believe, more specifically, that if we look into my report, the LIBE report, on which I was able to co-write – and I would also like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Peeters – we have ensured that there is more transparency in the algorithms, that users should have more opportunities to actually have a say in what they see in terms of content, that we have clear rules for notice and takedown, and that we have already made it clear – , that also decides on the Internet courts and that ultimately does not decide the platform. But what all three reports have in common – and I think this is an important sign – is that all three reports are clearly opposed to upload filters, to any filtering requirement de jure and de facto. I think that is a good sign, because this Parliament is emancipating itself today to a distance from a decision of the last period on Article 13. I know, dear Axel, we disagree, but I believe that this also sends a good signal to all the young people out there who have been on the streets, who have been disappointed with Parliament's decision, but who now see that it makes sense to get involved in this European democracy, because we also perceive, absorb and improve these things. And that, I think, is a strong sign today. But we are now setting many important rules or we want to set many important rules with this Digital Services Act. However, we should also work to make it better in Europe not only to lay down rules, but also to enforce them. We see this in the General Data Protection Regulation: we have come up with great rules, and in the end the big platforms still do not comply with them. We should therefore also pay particular attention to the Digital Service Act to set wise, correct, realistic rules, and we should, above all, ensure that these rules are enforced in Europe as well. That is what it is all about.

name: Christine ANDERSON
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The Digital Services Act is therefore supposed to be the EU's panacea for putting online platforms on a leash. However, there are also significant risks and side effects here.  One side effect, for example, is the so-called fact checkers. The problem is that fact-checkers don't check facts, they check content for the right – politically desired – attitude. The Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung aptly stated that this was the case – and I quote: "The journalist's office Correctiv, which facebook hired as an anti-fake news brigade, should apply the same standards to others, be blind in no eye and not just research in one direction." The next step in ordeal is the so-called upload filters, which prevent politically undesirable opinions from being published in the first place. We saw how this works in the US last week: It appears that presidential candidate Joe Biden is embroiled in a major corruption scandal in Ukraine, which the New York Post wanted to address in a publication. But because it cannot be what cannot be, this article on Facebook and Twitter was blocked by upload filters. And so the world is unaware of Biden's corruption scandal. And there's really good hope that Trump will actually be re-elected. In any case, I wish him every success in this. Article 5 of the Basic Law guarantees freedom of expression and says unequivocally: 'Censorship does not take place'. But a Union that tramples underfoot the constitution of its member states is not only not democratic, it is anti-democratic, dictatorial and totalitarian. As a German and as a supporter of the German Basic Law, I say: we do not need a Digital Services Act, we do not need an EU, we need an exit. The sooner the better! Exit now!

name: Kim VAN SPARRENTAK
text: – Mr President, what you and I get to see on the internet is based on what gives big tech companies the highest profits for their shareholders. Their algorithms decide what we get to see, based on clicks, manipulation and micro—targeting. But the Digital Services Act is our opportunity to rethink and reclaim our internet. We see now that extreme content is often promoted and queer content is sometimes censored by big platforms, but we have no way of holding platforms accountable for these decisions. We can only protect the freedom of speech and the freedom of information if we know what is actually happening online and we regulate the players who control it. Online platforms must be transparent about what they show to whom and why, but also about what they delete from the internet. Only then can we hold online platforms accountable. We need to take the internet back from big corporations and put it back into the hands of the people.

name: Geert BOURGEOIS
text: Mr President, on artificial intelligence, the US, China and Japan are already on the spurt, while the EU is still on its way. We have too little innovation, too few start-ups and too few patents. That is why, Madam Vice-President, we need to invest massively in research. We see our best researchers and our best students being taken away by foreign countries. Set concrete targets on the number of patents to be achieved, on start-ups and on implementation of AI by existing companies. Regulate, colleagues, yes. But research by the German Federal Ministry has indicated that 60% of implementations are risk-free. The remaining 40% already has sector regulations. It is therefore important to regulate in a targeted way and to protect citizens and consumers, but not to slow down development.

name: Sandra PEREIRA
text: – Mr President, today we are debating artificial intelligence, its impacts on the present and how we think it should impact the future of our societies.  While it is true that it is appropriate to discuss the ethical issues associated with the development and production of artificial intelligence technologies, as well as issues related to civil liability regimes and their need for adequacy and adaptation to new realities, it is also certain that, although the documents contain some positive points, this discussion is made in an inclined plane , a capital-based plan, which is essentially aimed at distaking responsibility for producers and manufacturers, where ethical issues focus more on the promotion and development of war-related technologies than on the impacts of artificial intelligence on workers' lives. At a time when there is so much talk of technological development, digital economy, artificial intelligence, industry 4.0, to impose new attacks on the rights and law of the jungle in working hours, more important becomes to bring to debate the impacts of these important scientific and technological advances on the lives of workers.  Artificial intelligence and robotics contribute to increasing the social productivity of human labor. Increased productivity creates the conditions for real wage increases and a better life, but this potential is constantly called into question in capitalist society for the sake of defence and increased profits.  It is at these moments that it is necessary to take sides. We want to put the potential of science and technology at the service of progress and social justice or, on the contrary, to the service only of the exploitation and accumulation of profit of a minority. Workers' rights and scientific advances are allies, they are not enemies, even if the latter are used so often as a tool of pressure and blackmail of the patronage. Artificial intelligence must be an ally of reducing working hours, combating precariousness and job hardwork, without this meaning loss of income for workers. It has to be allied in improving working and living conditions. This is the debate we bring and that is what we are committed to.

name: Lefteris NIKOLAOU-ALAVANOS
text: Mr President, new digital technologies and artificial intelligence are modern ways of ejecting the profitability of monopolies. European groups' confrontations with others — mainly Chinese and American — over market dominance on the uncertain terrain of the capitalist crisis are fierce. European monopolies are rewarded with tens of billions of euros from the Recovery Fund and the Multiannual Financial Framework, all of which are money from the toil of the peoples, to win the monopolies.  The self-control of groups, respect for rights, personal data and the moral use of the information gathered, only look like a joke. The increasing censorship of posts — with or without algorithms — supposedly against radicalisation shows that the status of new technologies is dictated by the interests of the owners, i.e. by the large groups they treasure.  The prevention of conflicts is unconvincing, as it is admitted that new types of weapons systems are already being used by NATO and the European Union and imperialist interventions are being made against the peoples to serve their geopolitical interests, while the reports prepare the ground for monopolies to come out of oil in any case.  In the race for ruthless capitalist profit, great technological achievements are turning into shackles, increasing unemployment, insecurity and the exploitation of workers, such as teleworking. The Euro folder, the bulk collection, storage, processing and marketing of personal data takes off.  Real liberalisation of all their potential can only be ensured by socialist production relations, without exploitation, monopolies and capitalist profitability.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: Before we continue the debate, we will begin today's voting period. We will vote on the dossiers as indicated on the agenda.  The voting period will run from 7:15 pm to 8:30 pm. Voting is carried out according to the same procedure used in the last voting periods. All votes will be carried out by roll call vote. You will be able to check your votes and the results of the votes by consulting the document published on the plenary website. Explanations of vote may be submitted in writing and, exceptionally, only explanations of vote with a maximum of 400 words will be accepted. I declare the voting period open. You can vote by 8:30. The results of the vote will be reported tomorrow at 9:00. I take this opportunity to make a warning. Following the appointment of our colleague Miriam Dali as member of the national parliament, the European Parliament declares the corresponding vacancy, with effect from 19 October 2020, following the usual procedure.

name: Edina TÓTH
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European Technology helps to solve people's everyday problems, it performs a number of amenities, with the possibility of continuous improvement. At the same time, the power, economic weight and undisputed social impact of technology giants have brought it to the attention of all EU Member States. Our task in the European Parliament is to ensure the maximum security of our citizens in the online space and to guarantee the democratic core values of transparency and accountability. It is important that what is illegal outside the online field should also be considered illegal in the online space. To this end, platforms should take greater action to quickly detect and remove illegal content. Illegal content can only be combated if Member States act in a coordinated and collective way, taking into account national aspects. Digital giants use algorithms to influence our lives on a daily basis, to influence our consumption habits and decisions. It is therefore important that consumers are informed when a digital service uses AI and that a remedy for an error in the nature of that service must be guaranteed. If problems are not tackled, AI can lead to misjudged decisions and influence decisions with false data. One of the biggest challenges of our time is whether we will be able to exit the digital bubble and dominate technology, or let technology take control of our lives. In my opinion, we need to create an artificial intelligence ecosystem that serves people's interests, focuses on people.

name: Eva KAILI
text: – Mr President, I’d like to express my thanks for the efforts made during these challenging times of the pandemic, when people actually expect fast and safe technological solutions; in parallel scientists need access to quality data that are collected faster but with clear consent. So we need to make sure citizens have options when data is collected, when they are recorded on their mics and cameras, and their locations recorded, and we definitely need immediately to set standards, clear standards, to remove regulatory obstacles for a real harmonised digital single market. At the same time we need to make sure, in order to protect our European quality of life, that the design of algorithms, and the metrics that we request, will be bound by legislation in order to translate ethical principles and human rights to the digital era – by law to ensure that we will not compromise safety or privacy with extra security criteria, and will make sure that automation remains under human control. In this case we can avoid exclusion or manipulation of perception, predicting the policing or ranking of citizens and the profiling of citizens. In that case we can collaborate more with democracies to protect our democracies.

name: Irena JOVEVA
text: – Dear President! We all know that the line between 'online' and 'offline' has long since broken. We all know what the real-world real-world real thing has in virtual, and we all know that the current trend of the company's digital transformation has only accelerated. But where does the current structure lead? The structure of opacs algorithms that determine how the world is displayed to us based on our personal information sold to whoever is willing to give the most money to them. When misinformation spreads much faster than anything verified, and when algorithms know exactly who is most receptive to conspiracy theories.  This structure leads to the easy manipulation of voters, the organized spread of disinformation and conspiracy theories, the sale of illegal, harmful products, hate speech, even incites violence and unfortunately often actually leads to violence.  All this - not least because of those politicians who abuse people's fear and anger for their interests and wage a cultural war with the media and the ghosts of the past - all of this purposely undermines people's trust in the profession and authority, undermines the quality of public debate and general culture and, consequently, makes it impossible to solve people's real pressing problems.  Political manipulation and battles of interest in the field of our personalities are the greatest threat to democracy. Therefore, the key highlights of the Reports of the Digital Services Act, the transparency requirements for algorithms, the labelling of the origin of advertising and misleading information and clear rules for the moderation of content online are key.  We are trying to find an appropriate level between freedom of speech and reporting and the privacy of Internet users and protection against malicious content. People should know what and who is behind the display of content, and let them have control over their identity.  While internet giants are making slow progress in protecting both users and our democracies, it is essential that we remove a monopoly on public space from private corporations and their algorithms and demand more transparency and more accountability.

name: Jean-Lin LACAPELLE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are on the cusp of a major technological revolution, that of artificial intelligence. This revolution will change our way of life and we, as legislators, have a duty to plan and prepare for the world that is coming. Some reject technical advances, they oppose the roboticization of our production systems, they imagine taxes on artificial intelligence and robots, taxes that will harm our competitiveness. They oppose the technologies, such as 5G, that are needed to digitize our societies. They forget that every innovation that Europe sees is going away, every patent we do not file, every start-up that leaves our continent is a weapon handed over to our foreign competitors. Others imagine a post-human world where man will be part of the machine, where liberalism has gone so far as to change the place of man: these apostles of transhumanism must also be fought. But a synthesis between power and ethics is possible. Our Greek and Christian philosophical heritage allows us to navigate the murky waters of modernity. However, this path can only be ours if we emerge from our lethargy. As of today, the Commission must stand up to the American and Chinese giants of artificial intelligence, ban them from collecting our data, promote the emergence of European giants, invest in research and development, better pay our researchers to avoid leaving with our competitors. All this can only be done by abandoning your outdated vision of free and undistorted competition. The opening of access to all markets, equality allowing all, without any distinction, to deploy in Europe: all this must stop. And when you give it up, you'll need a strategy. You have already tried it with the European data cloud Gaia X, last June, but your dogmas have caught up with you and you have scrupulously sabotaged this indispensable project by opening it to non-European companies. Colleagues, let us not miss this last opportunity to keep our European countries in the concert of nations. The survival of our civilization and our independence are at stake.

name: Gwendoline DELBOS-CORFIELD
text: – Mr President, in this joint debate, we have covered a broad range of subjects, but I will emphasise how much artificial intelligence has an impact on structural inequalities in our societies.  We ask for legislation guided by strong ethical principles with the protection of citizens and the environment as a priority. Regulation must address racial and gender-based discrimination. Such systems need to be subject to constant review and analysis. Further research is needed on the way in which algorithms perpetuate harmful biases. When content is considered problematic or dangerous, who decides how it’s removed from platforms? We are particularly concerned that introducing a separate category of legal but harmful context will lead to online censorship. The text does not contain clear enough language on upload filters. Even more worrying is the call for an electronic identification scheme that paves the way for master variance. This is a huge issue. Most of all, we must reiterate the importance of digital education. Only by equipping citizens with facts and enabling them to identify disinformation and misinformation can we make sure that we have an inclusive digital transformation.

name: Joachim Stanisław BRUDZIŃSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Today, the whole civilized world is in shock after the cruel murder carried out by an orthodox barbarian on a French teacher. Today is also the tenth anniversary of the murder committed for political reasons in Poland on law and justice activist Mark Rosiak. What do these murders have in common? Sick hatred and the fact that there are people on the internet glorifying and even calling for similar actions.  It therefore welcomes the direction taken in this report to remove illegal content without undue delay, especially those concerning children and of a terrorist nature. The new rules must contribute to enhancing online security and combating cybercrime, while ensuring the protection of the fundamental rights of internet users, in particular freedom of expression and the right to information.  Attention should be paid to the danger of censoring content in terms of its compatibility with the political correctness imposed by the left-liberal elites. There must be no agreement to restrict the right to freedom of expression, e.g. in the field of philosophical matters, under the banner of combating illegal content.

name: Tomasz FRANKOWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by As a Member of the PPE Group, responsible for working on the three opinions of the Committee on Culture and Education in the European Union legal framework for digital services, I would like to say that this legal framework needs to be updated to reflect the rapid digital transformation. We are therefore looking forward to an ambitious package of legislative proposals from the European Commission.  From the point of view of the Committee on Education and Culture, I would like to draw attention to two points. First, it's a problem to remove illegal content immediately. This is especially important if you're violating live content, such as sporting events or music concerts. In its opinion, the Committee on Culture has called on the European Commission to clarify what it is to remove without delay the illegal content already referred to in Article 14 of the E-Commerce Directive. Online intermediaries should react as soon as they receive notification from rights holders, up to a maximum of 30 minutes. This is crucial when removing illegal live content.  Secondly, I would also like to mention the amendment that my political group tabled with regard to the Saliba report from the IMCO Committee. I hope that it will receive broad support from all political groups. In this amendment, we would like to add a reference to the Audiovisual Services Directive. It is worth recalling that the digital services act should apply without prejudice to other sectoral legislation, such as the Copyright Directive or the Data Protection Regulation. Unfortunately, at this point, this reference to the Audiovisual Services Directive is missing, and i therefore ask you to support this amendment in the vote.  I also very much regret that, unfortunately, there is no specific paragraph in the annex to the Report of the Committee on Legal Remedies which makes it clear that the legislation on digital services should provide a horizontal framework complemented by existing and future sectoral rules, such as copyright and the Audiovisual Services Directive, and that the legislator will avoid conflicts of laws. I hope that when we receive a legislative proposal from the European Commission, we will have a clear reference on this issue.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I am speaking from the European Parliament's Liaison Office in Munich and I am very pleased that these new opportunities have been created. Connected products are increasingly being used, algorithms influence consumer decisions, they control connected household goods, even make decisions about creditworthiness or in a human resources department. These are all achievements that are very beautiful, very good.  However, we must remember that this also involves dangers and can also cause damage. That is why it is right and proper that we have thought about how we can adapt liability law to developments in the field of artificial intelligence. For us Social Democrats, a few specific points were particularly important, and I would like to single out three of them. One is that it is very important to us that not only physical damage but also non-material damage is addressed. Algorithms may be fed distorted data and can lead to incorrect decisions being made, which can be highly discriminatory. They can mean, for example, a denial of credit, and that is absolutely unacceptable. We must ensure that we have answers to them.  Secondly, we need liability not only from the manufacturer of the product, but also from the software developers, because they may have better and greater control over the procedure in this area.  Thirdly, we want the burden of proof to be fully reversed. If, for example, a coffee machine is defective, we will notice it very quickly and may also be able to see, as consumers, why this is actually the reason. However, if it is a software product, we cannot, and it is therefore important that the burden of proof does not remain with consumers. That is why we are appealing to the European Commission: fundamental rights must in any case be respected in all areas of artificial intelligence. The new rules must be created in a consumer-friendly manner and must be considered in the risk assessment of all dangers and damage. In addition, the Product Liability Directive needs to be modernised.

name: Sandro GOZI
text: Mr President, with the COVID-19 crisis, we have all entered digitalisation irreversibly, but our rules are already more than 20 years old, which, in digital technology, is more than a century behind schedule. Delay, because the virtuous circle full of opportunities presented to us by the internet shows us today its limits. Innovation and competitiveness are at stake, and so are civil liberties and security. The terrible attack that took place this weekend in France, in Conflans, shows us once again the urgency of legislating and assuming our responsibilities. Let's be brave! Today, we call together to develop a digital market without disproportionate and unjustified national barriers, to face the risks that exist for citizens, to increase and to frame the responsibility of platforms. Parliament's programme is ambitious and I hope, Commissioner, Madam Vice-President, that the Commission will be even more ambitious on the duty of care and on the fight against illegal content and practices. No complacency should be allowed towards illegal content on social networks. As has been said, being free means above all being responsible. This maxim applies to all of us, citizens or platforms, whether in real life or virtual: call for citizenship on the Internet and think of the victims of today and tomorrow.

name: Gunnar BECK
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Digitisation is necessary, carries risks, but also opportunities. It is necessary because international competition forces structural change and modernisation, and without adjustments, no economy will survive. Digital change carries risks – certainly – but the bill provides poor protection for users and their data, and parliamentary reports no longer as first aid.  After all, the Commission and Parliament are not concerned with consumer protection at all, but, as is almost always the way in which it is important to interpret not only illegal content, but also unwanted content. The aim is to share online only what pleases – not the users, but the judiciary, the public prosecutor and a new EU agency for this purpose. Our trust here is more John Stuart Mill and his belief in the vision of reason – not by decree or censorship, but by freedom of expression in the decentralized competition of ideas.  And let us be honest: digital change and artificial intelligence are the saving of us when natural intelligence becomes scarce as a result of fewer and fewer young Europeans. Artificial intelligence releases scarce human intelligence and is cheaper than unqualified immigration in social policy.

name: Dace MELBĀRDE
text: – Mr President, artificial intelligence is set to unchain the next wave of digitalisation that Europe so desperately needs. As past experience has shown, automation creates more jobs, increases productivity and improves the living standards of societies.  Unfortunately, to date, the EU has been slow in embracing AI. Even the discussions are delayed and focus primarily on the potential risks of AI and the need for regulation, as opposed to the enormous opportunities it provides.  Meanwhile, the development of AI as well as public and private investment in it is lagging behind other regions in the world. To catch up, the EU should turn to soft law solutions for AI and incentivise developers who promote trustworthy AI, as stated in a recent non-paper signed by a group of Member States.  Innovation and proportionality – not restriction – is the way forward.

name: Pilar del CASTILLO VERA
text: – Mr President, Madam Vice-President of the Commission, in the report of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection on the future law on digital services, the European Parliament sends a clear message on the need to adapt European standards to the digital age and the data economy.  The report, focusing on the revision of the E-Commerce Directive, is intended to be a valuable contribution to the Commission's imminent legislative proposal. The future rule should continue to respect principles well laid down in the Directive, such as the internal market clause, the freedom of establishment and the prohibition on imposing a general monitoring obligation on digital intermediaries.  Now the important thing, however, is that this e-commerce directive should be updated and thus, for example, clarify the content management liability regime and provide tools to deal with the growing volume of illegal goods, which are so damaging the manufacturing sector.  That said, the scope of the new proposal must go beyond the E-Commerce Directive and adapt the concepts of competition to digitisation. As has been done in other sectors, national regulators must have tools in place to address the growing number of barriers to access to data that companies encounter in trying to reach customers. I am referring to removing uncompromising access conditions, unlimited access to operating system functions or also legal transaction data.  In short, we must ensure that in a digital market all companies have access to third-party suppliers on a level playing field and transparency, because that will ultimately result in better services and further research.

name: Adriana MALDONADO LÓPEZ
text: – Mr President, Commissioner. First of all, I would like to value the role that the plenary of the European Parliament is having here today. Many months of work by different committees of the European Parliament are reflected here today in an intense, technical and solvency debate of different committees. I therefore think it is important that the Commission listens to the European Parliament and highlights the proposals which, through the various reports submitted by the European Parliament, we bring to the European Commission. They will therefore agree with me that the European Union has changed a lot from 1985 to 2020. That is why I would like to emphasise the Defective Product Liability Directive, which deals with that year. But society has changed so much, that this directive does not speak at any time of mobile phones, computers or telework, fundamental elements in the European economy, in the way we relate, in the way we work today in the 21st century. Therefore, for European Socialists, it is very important that this update of the 21st century be highlighted. It is true that around 50% of European product manufacturers today use artificial intelligence in their product processing processes; and it is also true that a large part of European citizens consider artificial intelligence not entirely their confidence in using their day-to-day life. Therefore, as legislators, we have the challenge of being able to work on a directive that gives confidence to the European institutions, but above all to our citizens. That security has to be without a doubt armed with the safety of many of our products.  And, as mentioned here too, it is essential that this burden of proof does not be on consumers. It is true that we need to empower our European consumers. We need European consumers to have a greater understanding of everything that has to do with new technologies, but a responsibility that has to be of producers cannot fall on them.

name: Maximilian KRAH
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Ladies and gentlemen, the European Union is the area with the lowest innovative power of the major economic areas in terms of IT and artificial intelligence. The music is set in the USA and Asia.  We are putting forward a new regulatory proposal that restricts freedom, but – and this has become typical in the meantime – creates a new agency and thus new civil servant posts. I am afraid that this is the wrong focus.  We can only regulate digital development if it takes place at all, and our regulation must promote it and not further restrict it. We do not need more civil servants, but more research. We do not need more regulation, but more freedom, and that applies not only to technology, but also to opinion.  Against this background, I believe that we should move away from a mind game based on legally taking every life risk and creating an agency for every possible violation of the law. We should return to the willingness to be able to withstand risks, because a risk always offers an opportunity. This is a chance for development to continue and for Europe to perhaps overcome its lack of innovation and to leave its regulatory strength behind.

name: Robert ROOS
text: Mr President, two weeks ago, I asked Commissioner Breton how he would ensure that content moderation on online platforms would not undermine freedom of expression. He argued that the focus of his policy would be on speeding up the targeting of content that is already illegal, such as terrorism and child pornography. Commissioner Breton has our support in this, of course. However, the European Parliament is going in the wrong direction. If it is up to this house, it becomes possible to repel inecurable or politically incorrect content under the guise of "harmfulness" from the social platforms, regardless of whether this content can also be considered illegal. Freedom of expression is the foundation of our free Western society, a core cultural value. I am counting on the Commission to recognise this danger and never allow this core cultural value to be compromised.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: – Mr President, this is an historic moment, the first time that the Plenary of the European Parliament has spoken about Helsinki and the best of themes: digitalisation and artificial intelligence. The current coronavirus pandemic has meant a big digital leap throughout Europe, and certainly some of these changes will remain permanent. At the same time, it has also highlighted the very big differences between regions and people and shows that we need to invest more in fast modern infrastructure and connectivity, in people's digital skills, and that we also need to invest more in research and innovation in digital services and in the sector in order to be competitive in the future. At the same time, therefore, this is also a signal to the current financial negotiations. Additional investments are needed for modern high-speed connections, people's digital know-how and research and product development in the field. It is the way in which Europe can remain competitive and successful in the future.  But in addition to investment and innovation, we need to ensure that we have legislation that supports new innovations and encourages the introduction of new technologies and new applications. At the same time, we must ensure that good consumer protection and people's fundamental rights are also realised in the digital world, and here it is important for us now in the legislation to find the right balance. We must not go out of our way to over-vote on digital services or artificial intelligence, but at the same time we must ensure that consumer and business confidence in digital services is maintained. This means that regulation needs to be reformed in terms of the responsibility of platforms, and we must also create our own ethical European principles for artificial intelligence.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, tomorrow's vote in Parliament lays the foundations for modern standardisation of digital services by reforming the e-commerce directive, which dates back to 2000, well before the excessive power of large platforms, when online commerce was much less widespread. At the same time, we will also have the first fruits of the work on artificial intelligence started together with the European Commission, establishing a general framework on the ethical aspects of civil liability and intellectual property, fundamental issues to guarantee citizens' confidence in this technology and to give legal certainty to the companies that use it. With the adoption of these reports, we are establishing a genuine European model for digital, based on human centrality and technology, on our fundamental rights and freedoms, on democracy itself. A framework that guarantees the protection of citizens and consumers, but also the promotion of innovation and excellence, in order to take full advantage of the great opportunities offered by new technologies and thus minimising the risks to our society.  I am particularly pleased with the specific focus on the counterfeiting of e-commerce, to which I have worked, up to the principle of "what is illegal offline is illegal online" and opening up the mandatory nature of some provisions, now voluntary, on the subject, we will protect European consumers and our companies even better from the proliferation of false and dangerous products, a trend, unfortunately, increased disproportionately during the Covid-19 pandemic. Let us therefore continue this work for an inclusive Europe at the forefront of digital transformation.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for It is time to accelerate when it comes to digital technologies. The COVID-19 pandemic has shown how important this area is to all of us in this difficult situation. We certainly need less bureaucracy and more digitalisation. So we should focus on innovation in this new perspective, and there is absolutely no doubt about that.  But with the development of digitalisation and access to online services, we should also pay great attention to protecting children from online abuse. And this issue is absolutely a priority for me, because we know that, unfortunately, this is very widespread in the European Union.  I would also like to point out that when designing solutions, it is important to bear in mind the balance between, on the one hand, the need for security and protection against online censorship, on the other hand, and the appropriate safeguards when it comes to freedom of expression and the right to information.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: – Mr President, the protection of intellectual property is an increasingly important topic at the time of the advent of AI. It is clear that the weight of mental work will continue to increase and its protection will become increasingly important. Until recently, the concept of intellectual property has been more or less clear. Someone made something or created it, and if someone else copied it without permission, he broke the law.  However, at a time of digital technology, more and more ambiguities are entering this area. We need to answer the questions that we would have recently put earlier in the world of science fiction. If AI can create, who will actually own the results of this creation? Who will be responsible for the autonomous decisions of the machines? And what if AI starts to form itself?  This may seem premature, but development is going at a tremendous pace and sooner or later we will be faced with these dilemmas. And that's when we need to have clear rules and clear legal frameworks. The guiding principle that we must bear in mind is that technology always serves man and society and not the other way round. However complex a machine or program is always, after all, only the result of human beings and work. Therefore, at the end of decision-making must always be human. Just as a person can always decide whether or not to use AI, only humans must have the final say in the decision-making process. Only in this way can we ensure that AI serves us, improves our processes and improves our services.

name: Javier ZARZALEJOS
text: –Mr President, the debate we are having is given by evidence that technologies have had and have a dramatic impact on business models and, at the same time, on the position of consumer and user rights.  We cannot give up what these technologies mean and do not submit to them as taxable persons. We therefore need a secure environment from a legal point of view, from a technological point of view and from the point of view of the protection that consumers expect. And it is therefore necessary, in the first place, for real harmonisation of national laws, clear rules on liability and the obvious affirmation of the principle that what is illegal offline, is also possible online.  We must certainly associate service providers to collaborate and provide conditions of transparency and legality. I mean that technology is true that it creates challenges, but also technology itself must help respond to them. That is why we must have the technology present and the one that develops in the future as a tool to solve the threats and risks specific to the online world. We understand that we must not prohibit, but must be regulated according to the maturity of each of the technologies.  And finally let me say that we need to maintain sectoral legislation to address the specific challenges and threats that exist in the digital world. These include the regulation of terrorist content after terrorism has once again attacked an innocent, victim of freedom in Europe.

name: Arba KOKALARI
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Many of us today in our connected world spend very many hours online. At the same time, online fraud, sex crimes and the sale of illegal products are also taking place. Hatred, threats and fake news are easily widespread, and we have seen this, not least now during the pandemic. We must both put an end to online crime, but also at the same time protect people's freedom online. It is a foundation of our democracy. In dictatorships, they find it difficult to keep these thoughts apart. But in europe, which still rests on a community of values, we have a responsibility to do so.  I would therefore like to see a new law in which internet platforms remove illegal content effectively, without creating incentives for these platforms to carry out online censorship. Because we all remember the debate about link taxes, upload filters and gdpr hassles. It is therefore crucial that we preserve the limitation of liability for platforms and ensure that only illegal content is removed, not satire or political opinions. For Europe to lead digitalization, and people in Sweden and the EU should be able to use digital platforms in a safe and secure way. But politicians' eagerness to clean up the internet must not go out over freedom of expression or create excessive hassle for small businesses, because then we do a disservice to both freedom and security.

name: Antonius MANDERS
text: Mr President, Commissioner, this issue in particular shows that the market is not waiting for the legislature. Artificial intelligence offers opportunities, but also brings threats. A lot has already been said. I will not go into that as a former lawyer. For that, one and a half minutes is far too short. But I call on the Commission to assure us that we do not become dependent on Chinese or American companies. I call on the Commission to ensure that European data actually remains in Europe. We can now make the rules that give us an edge over the rest of the world. We need to think about this in terms of content. Artificial intelligence and data are the oil of the future. If we get a head start on that, it will also offer Europe a great deal. For us, it is very important that artificial intelligence and legislation proposed for this purpose remains central to human beings. After all, we determine the laws, not artificial intelligence. Artificial intelligence should help to enable active ageing and re-engage older people in our society. 50% of the European population is 50 years of age or older. So half are older in the eyes of young people. But young people really want to be over 50. So in that respect, we're talking for everyone. Good legislation is important for everyone. I would therefore like to look forward to the Commission's proposals.

name: Tomislav SOKOL
text: – Dear Chairman, today we had a really high-quality discussion and we have heard many arguments about many aspects of digital market regulation. One of the most important, and this is something that has been mentioned repeatedly, it is a question of hate speech and freedom of expression. I would only mention, this way, that in addition to the crime, which has been mentioned several times, which took place in France, we were, unfortunately, last week witnessing an attack on the Government building of the Republic of Croatia in Zagreb, where unfortunately, a 22-year-old man shot around the Government building and seriously injured a policeman who was on guard, that is, in securing the Government Building. Unfortunately, it is obvious that this 22-year-old was motivated by hate speech and fake news on the internet, and worst of all, unfortunately, after the act took place, we could see a series of outbursts of glorification of his act, right on social media.  This shows how dangerous the spread of hate is online, shows how dangerous the spread of disinformation is and how much we must combat such phenomena. Of course, this does not mean that we need a "Ministry of Truth", this does not mean that we are in for censorship, it just means that we have to strike the right balance between freedom of expression on the one hand, but also hate speech, which is very dangerous and that can lead to tragedies like this in the future.  I am pleased that the Commission is acting in this direction, I am pleased that the measures announced are precisely towards achieving this balance and I believe that we will be able to achieve this balance and that we will protect all those values that constitute and protect the European way of life.

name: Alex AGIUS SALIBA
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, first of all my thanks to all the colleagues who participated in this very interesting discussion. I want to start my last intervention by quoting, as my colleague Tiemo did, the social dilemma: if you are not paying for it then you are the product. And this is the idea that we are fighting throughout our report, by increasing transparency, by increasing consumer protection – we must never treat our citizens just as simple products. Today we are living in a world where digital services and platforms are essential in our social and economic lives. Just imagine the consequences of the Covid-19 pandemic on our lives without digital infrastructure and without digital industries. These digital services basically helped us to continue with our commercial and social lives. But online platforms and digital services have largely evolved during the past 20 years and therefore, as EU legislators, we need to catch up. The ideas that we are moving forward in our reports are aiming at this target. Therefore we are directly asking the Commission to be ambitious, as we were in our reports, by introducing in its proposal these concepts: know your business customer principle, and know your business customer principle not only for online marketplaces but for all digital service providers; ex ante rules for digital sectors; special responsibilities for online marketplaces to guarantee consumer safety; stricter controls on targeted advertising and the AI mechanism; and a scope that will encompass companies established outside the EU which are targeting us and targeting our consumers. I want also to reply to a comment made by one of our colleagues and make it totally clear that our proposal is stating explicitly that what we are proposing is without prejudice to the Audiovisual Media Services Directive (AVMSD), to copyright law and to specific legislation. I hope that the report will gain your support in tomorrow’s vote.

name: Tiemo WÖLKEN
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner and now also Michael for the German Presidency! I would like to begin by saying a few words about today's debate. In fact, this was a very intense, very revealing meeting. There was also a great deal of concern for consumer rights, and on this point there is also an amendment to the report in the Committee on Legal Affairs. Tomorrow I will recommend the rejection of the amendments in this area, because I believe that they would have been included in the IMCO report, and because I also believe that we could have discussed these issues very well in the shadow rapporteur meetings.  I would like to say two or three words about the report 'IP rights for artificial intelligence', where I was shadow rapporteur: I believe that the success of artificial intelligence also depends largely on the availability of data, and it does not only help to train algorithms, but we must ensure that they operate without discrimination, and for that we need the sharing and sharing of data. And we need this in order to break up data monopolies and make the Digital Single Market fair for all market participants. This would encourage innovation in Europe. However, it is important to us Social Democrats that there should be rules on intellectual property rights that do not have the effect of affecting the sharing and recycling of data. We reject the concept of data ownership, as well as rules that would have the same effect in practice. At the same time, however, we must pay close attention to ensuring that the fruits of the work of human creators are adequately protected. At a time when more and more works are being developed using AI-based tools, and when AI is increasingly able to generate works independently without any human input, the value of human labor must be recognized, especially in the arts and creative sectors.  And a final sentence on the other DSA: we have made it clear here today that we are concerned with freedom of expression on the Internet and that we are prepared to fight for it. We look forward to the Commission's proposal in December.

name: Kris PEETERS
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank you for this debate. The core ideas for the Digital Services Act (DSA) are clear. The DSA must improve the framework for digital service providers to stimulate growth, but it must also make the fight against illegal content more successful and it must improve transparency and oversight. Our core idea for digital intelligence should be clear as well. Either we develop AI based on our own values and with economic benefits or we end up using AI developed on other continents without those values and without a large part of the economic benefits. A strong risk—based approach offers the best way forward here.  These challenges are difficult, but I fully support the efforts of all the rapporteurs here today. We are not even close to a satisfying legal situation, but these reports are an excellent start. Madam Commissioner, listening to your reaction, I am very positive about the proposals that you will make and we can discuss very soon.

name: Axel VOSS
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Vice-President Vestager, Mr Roth. I think it is nice, Mr Roth, that you have come to this really important debate this evening, and I would also like to refer again to what I said earlier. How do we manage to put all the good ideas that are now coming from the Commission or also from Parliament into the Member States?  If Europe does not succeed in acting as one at the end of the day, we will ultimately not be able to win competition with China and the United States. That is why, I believe, we need a different mind set in the Member States, namely that we pursue a European objective and not a national objective at European level. I do not know how we can achieve this, and it should not be a reproach to you, because I know that you are in a very different position. But I believe that this is one of the most important things about why we will not succeed if we do not make progress with Europe, or why we will not be able to implement it accordingly. That is why I believe that we must work to ensure that we really act as one. Of course, the individual points we have presented today are only a small building block. We also need many, many other small points, whether money, investment and infrastructure, etc., in order to become digitally sovereign in order to keep up. It is, I believe, also up to the Member States that we are blocking ourselves too much here, and I would ask that we make further progress on this. I believe that we need a sensible strategy, a concept in this regard, and I believe that what we have heard today can also be improved by the Commission itself.  Ultimately, I believe that we must also enforce the rules that we have afterwards. But in all this there is no way around the fact that we have to act as a unit and orient ourselves forward and not just be careful that things are going well in France, Germany, Spain, etc. in some way. As Europe, we must take the step forward in its entirety.

name: Axel VOSS
text: Executive Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, this has indeed been a rich, nuanced, very, very good debate. We have come from liability, intellectual property rights, innovation, hate speech, upload filters, consumer protection – I think we have shown the width and the depth of the work that has been ongoing here.  But, the thing is that the fundamental question is answered with a ‘yes’. Can we have a European model? There are other models, obviously. But the debate tonight has shown with all clarity that no one wants just to leave that to the state. Neither will anyone just say, ‘well, let business take care of this’. Now this has been a promise: that democracy will shape our society. That promise has been given tonight by everyone who has been taking the floor, that in our democracy we will shape this – for the state, for the business community, to serve the real asset here, which is the individual citizen, and that I find extremely promising.  Obviously, the level of complexity is quite high. There’s been a lot of very nuanced speeches, trying to balance that on the one hand, there are so obviously things that should not be out there, because it’s illegal in the offline world, while at the same time, no one wants censorship, no one wants the state to control. No one wants to limit a debate that can be free and nurture our democracy and that, of course, is the thing that we will have to grapple with in the months to come.  I just read an article in a Danish paper, in Danish, about artificial intelligence and part of that article was written by AI, in my mother tongue, on a rather complex subject, and I couldn’t distinguish what was written by the authors and what was written by AI. Maybe the grammar was slightly better by the AI – I wouldn’t know, but it’s just to say that when we’re in a world where artificial intelligence can write an op-ed, can write a poem, can write music, and we cannot tell the difference anymore, then it’s about time that democracy catches up with technology. Otherwise we cannot stand by the promise that the humans are the empowered here and that the machine is a servant.  The thing is that now the digital world, the online world, is not another world. It’s our world. For the children who are being bullied, it is just as real as when it was in the schoolyard back in the day. For the people who decide not to participate in democracy because of the hate speech online, it is as real as if someone has threatened them offline. This is our world and this is now, when we went to frame it, because it has matured. Back in the digital stone age, in the year 2000, of course, how could we have known any better? But this is the time and with this level of complexity, what a pleasure it is to see that we then discuss the principles. What are the fundamentals? That humans are in control; that transparency, responsibility, accountability, is what we want to work with; that you should know your customer; that you should be able to identify yourself to create the trust that people know who they are dealing with and you know that you are in control of the data that you create.  The principle of freedom, of fair markets. I think that is the core of the debate today and then, of course, the obvious: that the legislation that we will discuss and hopefully decide upon, should be implemented, should be enforceable, so that these promises are not empty, that it’s not just more words on paper, but that it’s real rights for citizens, for businesses, in the real world, to make the best possible use of digital technologies. It is, of course, a framework of legislation. It is the Digital Services Act, the Digital Market Act, it’s the legislation on artificial intelligence. It will be the Data Governance Act and the Data Act and the European Digital Identity, just to mention the most obvious things.  That should create ecosystems of excellence – because Europe has so much to offer. We have a culture of doing this and we will do it again. This is how we can create an ecosystem of trust, so that citizens do not feel estranged to a society that they have seen in the movies and found fascinating, but never ever wanted to live in. And obviously, as was just said, this is a European debate that should be rooted in every Member State. As we have seen with all the different proposals coming in every Member State because this is not just something down in Brussels. This is grown from every Member State but it needs a European response and this response you have given tonight by a promise that democracy will make sure that we frame this. (Applause)

name: Marcel KOLAJA
text: The joint debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 20 October 2020. Written statements (Rule 171)

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Writing. – The types of digital services and the roles of digital service providers have changed significantly since the e-commerce directive was adopted 20 years ago. In changed circumstances, Member States have started to define online services differently (e.g. NetzDG in Germany, France's law on illegal online content, etc.) and this would inevitably lead to fragmentation of the European Union's single market. It is therefore essential to modernise the definition of online services. The main positions of the e-Commerce Directive should certainly be maintained in the modernisation process: the principle of limited liability, the principle of the country of establishment (COO) and the principle of the general prohibition on the obligation to observe. The regulation of digital services should not impose disproportionate new obligations on businesses. Nor should regulations undermine innovation. I am categorically opposed to the public sector banning the use of AI-based facial recognition systems. We must protect people's privacy, but we must not kill innovation. I do not consider it reasonable to ban targeted advertising. As a consumer, I prefer to get information about the goods and services that really interest me in drowning in the noise of a flat-out ad. With a heavy heart, I supported the compromise proposal.

name: Patryk JAKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "Artificial intelligence is a very difficult subject in legal terms. It must be made clear that it is impossible to accept a state in which the decision-making process is completely independent of man. Artificial intelligence comes with many amenities, makes our lives easier, no doubt helps, but can't be held accountable. It must always be the responsibility of man for all processes based on it, for designing and creating them. Nor can there be any transfer of any powers of state authorities to machines.

name: Ondřej KOVAŘÍK
text: in writing. – I believe that AI can make a huge contribution to improve the lives of European citizens. AI is a strategic engine that contributes to improving productivity and economic growth. AI is also transforming the way we interact with money helping to streamline and optimize greater access to financial services and efficiency of operations. AI is a powerful ally when it comes to preventing and battling money laundering. Its sophisticated technology not only settles the infrastructure to recognise suspicious activity, but also helps to cut the costs of investigating alleged money-laundering schemes. However, as AI flourishes beyond the realm of science & research and penetrates into our daily lives, lawmakers should commit to steering it in a direction that benefits the common good. AI also raises a number of ethical challenges since it can potentially entail risks for EU citizens’ fundamental rights. The challenges presented by AI circle around the balance between the need to take advantage of this technology and the development of leading regulatory standards that puts people first. AI should be a human-centric technology. I believe it is necessary to establish a comprehensive European legal framework that enables technically robust AI development, while setting up ethical standards.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – When it comes to digitalisation of the economy, the truth is that we missed already several opportunities. We missed the opportunity created by the previous crisis to change the structure of capital investment in Europe and to increase the share of ICT; we also missed the opportunity of the start of this technological revolution when the main giants were created, when the new services were established. Today we have two opportunities at the same time. First, it is the economic crisis created by COVID19 that is pushing us to change the model. Second, it is the Artificial Intelligence (AI) and data breakthroughs that are happening. It gives us a chance to be back in the global digital competition, having in mind that Europe produces huge amounts of industrial data. We should use AI as a catalyst for the process of digitalisation and innovation in all industries. AI can be a solution to enhance Europe’s productivity which has been lagging compared to global competitors - and that is just one example. Understanding and addressing the current challenges faced by businesses will be key to ensuring Europe realizes the economic potential of AI to the fullest extent.

name: Beata MAZUREK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The Digital Services Code is an initiative aimed at improving the functioning of the Digital Single Market. Its main priority must be to remove barriers to its proper functioning while respecting the principles that underpin the existence and functioning of the Digital Single Market. Together with market improvements, it will be equally important to increase online security and protect the fundamental rights of internet users, as well as to introduce effective market surveillance with regard to the moderation of illegal content by intermediaries. Nowadays, where access to online content is widespread, transparent tools are needed to notify platforms and appeal to their decisions. Current rules and practices are not coherent, largely to the detriment of users and create chaos in the single market.  Another important element is to ensure the security of all network users by preventing and combating cybercrime. Improving cooperation between online platforms and competent enforcement authorities in individual Member States will be a key issue, while maintaining the highest guarantees of fundamental rights. There is a need for an effective mechanism to separate illegal content from legal but harmful or disinforming content. DSA must be a forward-looking solution that provides security and legal certainty for all users of the digital market.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. – The Digital Services Legislative Package is an essential element in the Digital Transformation of the European Union. Since the adoption of the E-Commerce Directive in 2000, the online environment has evolved significantly and that is why new ways are needed to regulate, define online platforms, stimulate innovation and support the European digital sector. At the same time, citizens were exposed to additional new risks while online companies faced difficulties in the possibility of challenging, fairness and market entry, especially in relation to large companies in the field.  That is why we need an open approach to regulating and developing the sector from the following directions: combating illegal, counterfeit or unsafe products and content; the implementation of a notification mechanism and the warning of offences; creating online seller profiles; the possibility to access platforms anonymously and to be forgotten by computer systems; implementation of all measures on platforms outside the EU. What is clear is that everything that is illegal offline becomes illegal and online, but everything that is good online must be actively and appropriately supported for the European Union to become a leader in online platforms.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: Written. "Digitalisation and artificial intelligence create incredible opportunities for our societies and for us humans and make our lives much easier in many ways. New emerging technologies are not good or bad in themselves; Digitalisation and new technologies are an important part of our everyday lives in many different ways. The related legislation should therefore be integrated into existing legislation, rather than creating completely separate digital legislation. What is illegal off-grid is also illegal online.
